{{For|Senegalese sprinter|Abdoulaye N'Diaye}} {{Infobox person | name =Abdoulaye Ndiaye | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Abdoulaye Ndiaye | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|03|15}} | birth_place = Medina Gounass, [[Senegal]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Entrepreneur gemologists | years_active = 1972-present | known_for = | notable_works = | website= }}
'''Abdoulaye Ndiaye''' (born on 15 March 1952) is a [[Senegalese]] businessman and entrepreneur based in [[Kitwe]], [[Zambia]].<ref name="BBG">[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-01/israeli-diamond-billionaire-leviev-buys-into-zambia-emerald-mine Billionaire Leviev Adds Zambia Emeralds to Diamond Portfolio] ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref><ref name="HBR">[https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-63299567.html Bells produce the gems] ''[[Mining Magazine]]'' Retrieved through ''[[HighBeam Research]]'' Publication date 1 June 2000, Retrieval date 5 Auguast 2017</ref><ref name="YAH">[https://ph.news.yahoo.com/israeli-diamond-billionaire-leviev-buys-093954282.html Zambia produced 74.7 metric tons of emerald and beryl] ''[[Yahoo News]]'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref>
==Early life== Abdoulaye was born in 1952, in Medina Gounass village in [[Senegal]]. He is commonly known as Gounass. He went to an [[Madrasa|Islamic school]] in Medina Gounass. Abdoulaye came to [[Zambia]] in 1972 and started his business of buying and selling of [[emerald]]s from Lufwanya on the [[Copperbelt Province|Copperbelt of Zambia]] until he bought an emerald mine in 1997.<ref name = "BBG"/><ref name ="IDE">[http://www.idexonline.com/FullArticle?Id=43137 Diamond Mogul Leviev Buys 50% of Zambian Emerald Mine] ''IdexOnline'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref> He later married in 1981 and settled in Kitwe where he established his other businesses. Abdoulaye is also a principal [[shareholder]] in International companies such as Ontario Group of Companies S.A, a real estate company based in [[Dakar, Senegal]], and Gounasse International Inc, a company involved in [[real estate]] as well as in the [[hospitality]] industry.<ref>[http://www.miningweekly.com/article/israeli-diamond-billionaire-leviev-buys-into-zambia-emerald-mine-2017-06-01/rep_id:3650 Grizzly was previously 85% owned by Abdoulaye Ndiaye] ''[[Mining Weekly]]'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref> ==Career== Abdoulaye started his career by buying and selling of emeralds. In 1997 he purchased an emerald mine on the [[Copperbelt Province|Copperbelt of Zambia]].<ref name="BBG"/> The major product that Abdoulaye's mine produces is raw and partially processed emeralds and [[beryl]].<ref name="HBR"/> Zambian Emeralds tend to have more of a bluish cast than either [[Brazil]]ian or [[Colombian emeralds]], and tend towards a slight grayish cast, which is not present in either Colombian or Brazilian Emeralds.<ref>[http://www.securitiesafrica.com/Documents/Docs/Weekly_African_Footprint_-_2_June_2017.pdf Emerald prices have soared by more than tenfold in the past eight years] ''Securities Africa'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref> The Zambian and Brazilian Emeralds may also be coloured due to the presence of [[vanadium]], whereas Colombian Emeralds usually achieve their coloration from the presence of [[chromium]].<ref name="YAH"/><ref name="EITI">[https://eiti.org/sites/default/files/zeiti_bo_report_-_final_version_13_07_15_0.pdf Zambia extractive industries transparency Initiative (zeiti)] ''[[Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative]]'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref>
Abdoulaye's companies have created employment and business opportunities for more than 800 people in [[Zambia]] and [[Senegal]], this in turn contributes significantly towards government revenue, in terms of various taxes.<ref name="EITI"/><ref>[http://www.jo.gouv.sn/spip.php?article8941 Ministere de l’economie et des finances - Arrete ministeriel n° 228 mef-dgid-dedt en date du 5 janvier 2011] ''Journal officiel de Senegal'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref>
|} ===Gemcanton=== Gemcanton is based in [[Kitwe]] and owned by Abdoulaye. The company contributes in [[Gemstone|gemstone mining]] including [[emerald]] and [[beryl]] production. The company focuses on improving the lives of indigenous people residing within the vicinity of mine-sites. Gemcanton has invested in education by constructing two community schools in the district, one of which has since been handed over to the Ministry of Education. The company is involved in the annual road maintenance works throughout the district.<ref name="BBG2">[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=433629619 Company Overview of Gemcanton Investments Holdings Limited] ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref> Gemcanton is the principal sponsor of [[Kitwe United F.C.|Afrisport Club]] from 2012, which is now playing in Division 2. [[Kitwe United]] were sponsored up to December 2012.<ref>[https://www.daily-mail.co.zm/grizzly-mining-gives-afrisport-k500000/ Grizzly Mining gives Afrisport K500,000] ''[[Zambia Daily Mail]]'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref> ===Grizzly Mining=== Grizzly Mining Limited was incorporated as mining company by Abdoulaye in 1997 and subsequently other companies were incorporated.<ref name="IDE"/> The company is headquartered at [[Kitwe]]. Grizzly Mining Limited is engaged in the production, processing, grading, marketing and supply of [[emerald]]s and [[beryl]].<ref>[http://strccollege.com/ballmill/grizzly-mining-ltd/ Ndiaye is the owner of Grizzly Mining Zambia] Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref><ref>[http://www.winne.com/division/ebizguides/webpublish/2011/zambia/files/assets/seo/page170.html Grizzly Mining Ltd. is Zambia’s leading gemstonemining company. Incorporated in 1999] ''Winne'' Retrieval date 5 August 2017</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Abdul Aziz bin Fahd |image=Prince abdulaziz bin fahad.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1973|4|16|df=yes}} (age 45) | birth_place = [[Riyadh]], [[Saudi Arabia]] | | spouse = Al Anoud bint Faisal bin Mishaal Al Saud | issue = | full name = Abdul Aziz bin Fahd bin Abdul Aziz Al Saud | house = [[House of Saud]] | father = [[Fahd of Saudi Arabia|King Fahd]] | mother = [[Al Jawhara bint Ibrahim Al Ibrahim|Al Jawhara Al Ibrahim]] }}
'''Abdul Aziz bin Fahd''' ({{lang-ar|عبدالعزيز بن فهد بن عبد العزيز آل سعود}}) is a [[Saudi Arabian people|Saudi Arabian]] Prince and member of the Royal [[House of Saud]].
==Early life and education== His mother is [[Al Jawhara bint Ibrahim Al Ibrahim]], belonging to the wealthy Al Ibrahim family.<ref name=ajcenter>{{cite web|title=HH Princess Al-Jawhara bint Ibrahim|url=http://al-jawhara-center.kau.edu.sa/Content.aspx?Site_ID=287&lng=EN&cid=40127|publisher=King Abdulaziz University|accessdate=14 May 2012|year=2010}}</ref>
Abdul Aziz bin Fahd received a bachelor of arts degree in administrative sciences from [[King Saud University]].<ref name=webpage>{{cite web|title=Index |url=http://www.abdulazizbinfahad.com/en_index.html |publisher=Web page dedicated to Abdul Aziz bin Fahd |accessdate=23 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502233511/http://www.abdulazizbinfahad.com/en_index.html |archivedate=2 May 2012 }}</ref>
==Professional experience== Prince Abdul Aziz was first appointed as minister of state without portfolio in May 1998.<ref name=sonline>{{cite web|title=The Council of Ministers|url=http://www.saudia-online.com/Government%20Council%20of%20Ministers.htm|publisher=Saudia Online|accessdate=8 September 2012}}</ref> Then, he was made head of the Office of the Council of Ministers in January 2000, when he was 28 years old.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sakr|first=Naomi|authorlink=Naomi Sakr|title=Whys and Wherefores of Satellite Channel Ownership|journal=Satellite Realms: Transnational Television, Globalization and the Middle East|year=2001|url=http://acc.teachmideast.org/texts.php?module_id=13&reading_id=1029&sequence=3|accessdate=13 May 2012}}</ref> It was reported that after [[Fahd of Saudi Arabia|King Fahd]]'s death, he began to live in [[Switzerland]] and came to [[Saudi Arabia]] to participate in the meetings of the Council of Ministers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prens Abdülaziz bin Fahd'ın çöküşü (The Fall of Abdulaziz bin Fahd) |url=http://www.diplomatikgozlem.com/TR/belge/1-7316/prens-abdulaziz-bin-fahdin-cokusu.html |publisher=Diplomatik Gözlem (Turkish, Diplomatic Observation) |accessdate=12 April 2012 |date=14 August 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615022826/http://www.diplomatikgozlem.com/TR/belge/1-7316/prens-abdulaziz-bin-fahdin-cokusu.html |archivedate=15 June 2013 }}</ref>
On 26 June 2011, he was relieved from his position as head of the court of Cabinet affairs by a royal decree.<ref>P.K. Abdul Ghafour (26 June 2011):[http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article462235.ece "Cabinet court merged with royal court"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110630104155/http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article462235.ece |date=30 June 2011 }}. Arab News.</ref> It was declared that he resigned from his posts of minister of State and member of the Council of Ministers at his own request in June 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fahd bin Abdul Aziz’s exemption from the Presidency of the Prime Ministry Cabinet Office|url=http://www.islamtimes.org/vdcg3y97.ak9t74j5ra.html|accessdate=6 May 2012|newspaper=Islam Times|date=14 June 2011}}</ref>
==Business activities== His ties with [[Saudi Oger]] were well known in [[Saudi Arabia]]. The company was founded by [[Rafik Hariri]], who built Saudi Oger into a large company with the assistance of [[Fahd of Saudi Arabia|King Fahd]]. Hariri said ‘The meat on my shoulder is from King Fahd,’ according to [[As'ad Abu Khalil]], a professor of political science at [[California State University Stanislaus]], who has written several books and runs the blog [[The Angry Arab News Service]]. Hariri, also a former prime minister of [[Lebanon]], was assassinated in 2005. His son, [[Saad Hariri]], took over Saudi Oger and became Lebanon’s prime minister for 14 months before he was ousted in 2011. Saad Hariri and Prince Abdul Aziz are known to be close.<ref name=russ>{{cite news|last=Buettner|first=Russ|title=At a Rape Trial, Two Views of a Prince’s Wealth|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/20/nyregion/at-rape-trial-2-views-of-a-saudi-princes-wealth.html?_r=2&partner=rss&emc=rss|accessdate=12 April 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=19 February 2012}}</ref>
Abdul Aziz bin Fahd owned fifty percent of the [[MBC Group|MBC]], of which the remainder is owned by his maternal uncle [[Waleed bin Ibrahim al Ibrahim]]. It is reported that Prince Abdul Aziz dealt with both the profits and the ideology of MBC Channels, including [[al Arabiya]].<ref name=wikileaks09>{{cite web|title=Ideological and Ownership Trends in the Saudi Media|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=09RIYADH651|publisher=Cablegate|accessdate=1 May 2012|date=11 May 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116083750/http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=09RIYADH651|archive-date=16 January 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
It emerged in a [[New York Supreme Court]] affidavit that he was the secret owner of a $1 billion property portfolio in the US <ref>{{cite news|author=Stephen Foley|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/revealed-saudi-royals-secret-1bn-us-empire-7817936.html|title=Revealed: Saudi royals' secret $1bn US empire|publisher=The Independent|date=6 June 2012|accessdate=29 July 2012}}</ref> which owns the American headquarters of the oil giant [[BP]] and the defence contractor [[BAe Systems]]. In January 2002 The Daily Telegraph newspaper valued the portfolio at £4 billion.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/8272597/Former-Credit-Suisse-executive-Pierre-Rolin-owes-43m.html |title=Former Credit Suisse executive Pierre Rolin 'owes £43m'|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref> The affidavit, which was subsequently partially sealed by the judge but had already become available on internet blogs <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/96621795/Secret-1B-Saudi-Property-Empire|title=Secret $1B Saudi Property Empire|publisher=Scribd|date=23 April 2012|accessdate=29 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sethhettena.com/2012/documents-reveal-secret-1b-saudi-property-empire/ |title=Docs Reveal Secret $1B Saudi Property Empire"Seth Hettena |publisher=Seth Hettena |date=10 June 2012 |accessdate=29 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815081659/http://www.sethhettena.com/2012/documents-reveal-secret-1b-saudi-property-empire/ |archivedate=15 August 2012 }}</ref> stated that the properties were being managed by a group which included Sheikh Majid Al Ibrahim, Prince’s maternal uncle, and that total control of the portfolio was ultimately seized by Interventure Capital Group and Interventure Advisers, both of [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. According to a press release issued by Hyatt Hotels Corporation,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investors.hyatt.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=228969&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1656251&highlight=|title=Hyatt Hotels Corporation|publisher=Investors|accessdate=29 July 2012}}</ref> Interventure Capital Group is run by Jaber Al Ibrahim and is an adviser to Naseel Holding Company, the Al Ibrahim family investment vehicle chaired by Sheikh Majid Al Ibrahim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naseel.com/message.asp|title=Chairman Message|publisher=Naseel|accessdate=29 July 2012}}</ref>
According to a report in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' in October 2010, Interventure Capital Group is also behind another major portfolio of properties which had been controlled by a UK-based company, StratREAL.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/8057153/Tory-donor-Pierre-Rolin-accused-of-stealing-30m-from-Gulf-investor.html|title=Tory donor Pierre Rolin accused of stealing £30m from Gulf investor |publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref> Assets purchased by StratREAL on behalf of Prince Abdul Aziz bin Fahd included Fifth Street Towers, a Minneapolis office complex, for $294 million in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=StratREAL|url=http://www.bensoncairns.com/stratreal/images/5_news/pr2007/Minnesota.pdf|publisher=Srtrategic Real Estate Advisors|accessdate=24 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160122035626/http://www.bensoncairns.com/stratreal/images/5_news/pr2007/Minnesota.pdf|archivedate=22 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In May 2012, following a foreclosure on the complex for mortgage default, Fifth Street Towers was sold at a sheriff's auction for $1 over the outstanding debt of $110 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Webber|first=Maura |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303630404577390702752284054|title=Venture Pays $1 Over Debt To Win Minneapolis Tower|work=The Washington Post|date=8 May 2012|accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref>
A mansion at 5 Palace Green, on London's [[Kensington Palace Gardens]] (nicknamed "Billionaires' Row"), was reported to be being offered for sale by Abdul Aziz in July 2013 for £100 million.<ref name='Hipwell 2013'>[http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/property/article3827926.ece Billionaire Saudi’s £100m London home up for sale], ''[[The Times]]'', 29 July 2013</ref>
==Alliances== Abdul Aziz bin Fahd was previously one of [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]]'s closest aides. However, later, he seemed to have had a falling out with the monarch and to have been close to his uncle, the late [[Nayef bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Crown Prince Nayef]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Kapoor|first=Talal|title=Nayif's Return – A Lame Duck Crown Prince?|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/viewCommentary.do?id=79251&pageNum=2|publisher=Datarabia|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref>
==Fortune== Abdul Aziz received exactly half of all profits of the successful Middle East Broadcasting Corporation (MBC).<ref name=wikileaks09/> He had a number of palaces in Saudi Arabia and around various other parts of the world which have cost over $2 billion<ref>[http://syrianthinkers.org/countries/saudi/articles/TheSaudiTrap.pdf The Saudi Trap] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728080139/http://syrianthinkers.org/countries/saudi/articles/TheSaudiTrap.pdf |date=28 July 2011 }}</ref> which include:
* London Mansion on the Billionaire's row in [[Kensington]], now for sale at £100 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://virtualglobetrotting.com/map/prince-abdul-aziz-bin-fahd-al-saud-mansion/|title=Prince Abdul Aziz Bin Fahd Al Saud Mansion |publisher=Virtual Globetrotting|date=2 August 2013|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref> * A very large private stately residential complex with the replica of [[Alhambra]] and several other famous forts set within well maintained splendid gardens covering an area of 134 acres in the exclusive area overlooking Wadi Hanifa in Riyadh. {{Coord|24.645808|N|46.643202|E}} * Massive farm near Janadriya covering an area of 715 acres or about 2.89 square kilometers at the northern outskirts of [[Riyadh]]. Satellite photos reveal large swimming pools, luxury tents and its own water and sewage treatment facility set within a large date farm.{{Coord|25.138224|N|46.79251|E}} * In [[Jeddah]] he has several palaces with private yacht berths and each palace has more than twenty guest houses .{{citation needed|date=October 2011}}
In addition, he reportedly owned "the Pyramid House" on Hillcrest Road in [[Beverly Hills, California]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Cavatore|first=Alison|title=Saudi Prince Reportedly Overhauling Beverly Hills Pyramid House|url=http://www.hauteliving.com/2013/02/saudi-prince-reportedly-overhauling-beverly-hills-pyramid-house/339276/|publisher=Houte Living|accessdate=2 February 2013|date=1 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://virtualglobetrotting.com/map/a-abdul-aziz-bin-fahda-pyramid-house/ |title=Abdul Aziz bin Fahd pyramid house |publisher=Virtual Globetrotting |date=2 August 2013 |accessdate=9 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807103557/http://virtualglobetrotting.com/map/a-abdul-aziz-bin-fahda-pyramid-house/ |archivedate=7 August 2013 }}</ref>
==Personal life== Abdul Aziz bin Fahd married Al Anoud bint Faisal Al Saud in December 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Crown Prince of Dubai to attend the wedding of Prince Abdulaziz bin Fahd Al Saud|url=http://fazza.ae/en/2010/12/22/the-crown-prince-of-dubai-to-attend-the-wedding-of-prince-abdulaziz-bin-fahd-al-saud/|publisher=Fazza|accessdate=6 June 2012}}</ref> His wife is a granddaughter of late [[Sultan bin Abdulaziz]] and of [[Mishaal bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Mishaal bin Abdulaziz]].<ref>{{cite news|title=الأمير عبد العزيز بن فهد يحتفل بزواجه من كريمة الأمير فيصل بن مشعل|url=http://www.alriyadh.com/2010/12/23/article588103.html|accessdate=6 June 2012|newspaper=Al Riyadh|date=23 December 2010}}</ref>
He dealt with camel racing in Saudi Arabia. His camels won the race organized in the Janadriyah festival in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques launches Janadriyah festival in the presence of Bahrain’s monarch|url=http://www.ainalyaqeen.com/arch_2011/april-15/en3.php|accessdate=6 May 2012|newspaper=Ain Al Yaqeen|date=15 April 2012}}</ref>
The Prince owns a [[Boeing 777]], a [[Boeing 737-BBJ2|Boeing 737 Business Jet]] and a [[Canadair Challenger]] which uses frequently for pleasure travel.<ref>{{cite web|author=Shauna DeFord|url=http://www.thetimesnews.com/news/top-news/graham-woman-travels-the-world-with-a-prince-1.55123 |title=Graham woman travels the world with a prince|work=The Times News|date=26 November 2012|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref>
==2017 purge== {{Main article|2017 Saudi Arabian purge}}
Before he was himself purged, he was used in the kidnapping of [[Sultan bin Turki II bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]]<ref>http://cnn.it/2RY1ye1</ref>.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/mystery-surrounds-fate-late-king-fahd-s-son-amid-saudi-intrigue-1517142278|title=Mystery surrounds fate of late King Fahd’s son amid Saudi crackdown|work=Middle East Eye}}</ref>
==Fate== The fate of Prince Abdul Aziz bin Fahd is uncertain. There were rumors that Abdul Aziz, age 44, was killed by a [[Tiger Squad|death squad]] while resisting arrest, but the Saudi information ministry released a statement saying that the prince was "alive and well."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/mystery-surrounds-fate-late-king-fahd-s-son-amid-saudi-intrigue-1517142278|title=Mystery surrounds fate of late King Fahd’s son amid Saudi crackdown|last=Akkad|first=Dania|date=2017-11-08|work=Middle East Eye|access-date=2017-11-10|language=en}}</ref> A year later, Prince [[Nawaf bin Faisal]] tweeted a video showing that Abdul Aziz bin Fahd is still alive.<ref>https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2018/11/7/amid-khashoggi-outrage-saudi-prince-rumoured-killed-re-emerges</ref>
==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Abdul Aziz bin Fahd Al Saud''' |2= 2. [[Fahd of Saudi Arabia|Fahd bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]] |3= 3. [[Al Jawhara bint Ibrahim Al Ibrahim]] |4= 4. [[Ibn Saud|Abdulaziz ibn Saud]] |5= 5. [[Hussa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi|Hassa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi]] |6= 6. Ibrahim Al Ibrahim |8= 8. [[Abdul Rahman bin Faisal]] |9= 9. Sarah bint Ahmed Al Kabir bin Mohammed Al Sudairi |10= 10. Ahmed bin Muhammed Al Sudairi |11= 11. Sharifa bint Ali bin Mohammed Al Suwaidi |16= 16. [[Faisal bin Turki bin Abdullah Al Saud]] |17= 17. Sarah bint Mishari bin Abdulrahman bin Hassan Al Saud |18= 18. Ahmed Al Kabir bin Mohammed bin Turki Al Sudairi |20= 20. Muhammed bin Ahmed Al Kabir Al Sudairi |22= 22. Ali bin Mohammed Al Suwaidi }}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Advania AB | logo = Advania_Ísland_ehf_-_logo.png | caption = | industry = [[Information technology]] | foundation = [[Reykjavík]], Iceland ({{Start date|1939|12|01}}) | location = [[Reykjavík]], Iceland | locations = 22 offices in 4 countries (2017) | area_served = [[Northern Europe]] | key_people = Gestur G. Gestsson Group CEO, Ola Maalsnes Group CFO, Mikael Noaksson Group CCO, Lilja B. Skúladóttir Group Controller, Tomas Wanselius CEO Advania Sweden, Ægir Már Þórisson CEO Advania Iceland, Espen Hartz CEO Advania Norway. | products = | services = Managed Services IT infrastructure & integration Business Solutions Professional Soultions - Communication Centers MarketPlace Data Center Services | revenue = | operating_income = 23.862 million ISK (2016) | net_income = | owner = Group of Swedish and Icelandic investors, led by Thomas Ivarsson chairman of the Board of Directors. | num_employees = 1,150 total 620 in Iceland 420 in Sweden 90 in Norway 20 others | footnotes = | homepage = {{URL|advania.com}} {{En icon}}
{{URL|advania.is}} {{Is icon}} }} '''Advania''' is a [[Nordic countries|Nordic]] [[information technology]] service corporation headquartered in [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]].{{Cite news | date = 20 January 2012 | title = Sameinast undir heitinu Advania | trans-title = Merge under the name Advania | url = http://www.mbl.is/vidskipti/frettir/2012/01/20/sameinast_undir_heitinu_advania/ | newspaper = [[Morgunblaðið]] | language = Icelandic | location = Reykjavík, Iceland | publisher = Árvakur }} The company is the largest in its field in Iceland and the 9th largest in the [[Nordic countries]]. Advania has corporate clients in the public and private sector. It provides a wide range of IT-services, platforms, cloud [[solution]]s and support to multinational enterprises, governments, big, small and medium-sized businesses. ==History== Advania traces its roots to three Nordic countries, [[Iceland]], [[Norway]] and [[Sweden]]. Over a long period of time each country generated a component of what eventually was braided into one company, Advania AB, in 2012. === The first branch was EJS === In 1939 the Icelandic entrepreneur Einar J. Skúlason founded '''EJS''', an office equipment repair workshop in Reykjavik. He soon expanded his business, opened a store and started importing office machinery, cash registers etc. During [[World War II]] the company also repaired guns and [[lighter]]s. EJS eventually became a dominant IT business in Iceland. In 1952 the [[Icelandic Government|Icelandic government]] and the city of [[Reykjavík|Reykjavik]] founded '''Skýrr''', an IT company whose purpose was to take a leading role in computing and recordkeeping in Iceland. The company was privatized in 1995 and later became the core element in a group of companies – including EJS – that merged under the Skýrr brand. === The Swedish branch was next to evolve === In 1971 the IT company Nokia Elektronic AB – later renamed Datapoint Svenska AB – was founded in Sweden. The company sold [[Datapoint]] computer terminals but later became a network pioneer and a key system integrator in Sweden. In 2003 Datapoint merged with Virtus AB, an IT-company which was founded in 1994 and grew rapidly. Virtus soon became a key player in the Swedish market, focusing on [[Microsoft]] based solutions and offering storage & backup services. In 2003 one the strongest and most comprehensive system integrators in Sweden was created when Datapoint and Virtus merged. The new company was named Kerfi AB. === And the Norwegian was third === In 1991 Merkantildata Applikasjon was founded in Norway, originally as a business unit within Merkantildata (later ATEA). The company focused on implementing ERP solutions in the Nordic market, industry solutions for retail, property management, logistics, legal and transport & waste management. In 2000 the company changed its name to Hands and was listed on the Oslo Stock Exchange. In 2005 Hands was unlisted, as it was acquired by the Icelandic company Kögun which later merged with Skýrr (see above). Despite changes in ownership Hands kept its Norwegian identity and acquired Nett.2.3 and Completo in 2005. In 2012 Advania AB was born, when Skýrr from Iceland, Kerfi from Sweden and Hands from Norway merged and became a key challenger in the Scandinavian IT-market.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Since then four companies have been acquired and merged with Advania, the listed Swedish IT company Caperio included. == Business Areas == [[File:Advania HQ.jpg|thumb|The Advania offices in Reykjavik, Iceland.]] Advania focuses on these four main business areas: === Managed Services === Advania offers a variety of managed services where clients can offload specific IT operations. === IT Infrastructure & Integration === Advania offers [[solution]]s for IT infrastructure, integration projects, consultancy and product support. Advania has data center solutions, IT platform projects, virtualization [[solution]]s, [[solution]]s focused on identity and access, as well as development, integration, and support of both software and hardware. === Business Solutions === Advania provides IT [[solution]]s to automate, streamline, measure, document and stimulate business and IT processes. === Professional Services === Advania provides a broad array of consulting services, software development, eBusiness services and infrastructure [[solution]]s for private and public bodies, local and international customer. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:2012 establishments in Iceland]] [[Category:Advania| ]] [[Category:Companies based in Reykjavík]] [[Category:Companies established in 2012]] [[Category:Companies of Iceland]] [[Category:Military industry]] [[Category:Privatised companies in Iceland]] [[Category:Software companies of Iceland]] [[Category:Cloud computing providers]]

{{Infobox company | name = Allied London | logo = | type = Property | foundation = 1909 | location = 1st Floor, 7-8 Savile Row, London, W1S 3PE | key_people = Chief Executive Officer: [[Michael Ingall]]; Finance Director: Freddie Graham-Watson; Development Director: Stuart Lyell; Consultant: Graham Skinner; Associate Director: Jonathan Raine; and Consultant: Philip Daniell | industry = [[Property]] | products = Various office, residential and leisure space | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | subsid = | homepage = [http://alliedlondon.com alliedlondon.com] | footnotes = }} '''Allied London''' is a property development and investment company that develops landmark projects ranging from re-use to regeneration developments across retail, commercial, office, residential, restaurant, and leisure sectors. The company also offers rental options. They own several buildings in the [[Spinningfields]] area of [[Manchester]], as well as [[Glasgow]], [[Leeds]] and [[London]].<ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite news | title = Company Overview of Allied London Properties Limited | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/Research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=5412604 | work = [[Bloomberg Businessweek]] | publisher= [[Bloomberg L.P.]] | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref>
== History == The company was founded in 1909 and became a private company with [[Michael Ingall]] as its CEO from September 2000.<ref name=Bloomberg />
==Properties== Allied London's properties include:
=== Manchester === [[File:Manchester Civil Justice Centre from Bridge Street.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Manchester Civil Justice Centre|Civil Justice Centre, Manchester]]]] * The Bonded Warehouse<ref name="Building_140814">{{cite news | last = Dunton | first = Jim | title = Ian Simpson to design new Granada Studios | url = http://www.building.co.uk/-ian-simpson-to-design-new-granada-studios/5070337.article | work = Building.co.uk | date = 14 August 2014 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> * [[St John's Quarter|The Old Granada Studios]]<ref name="MEN_300715">{{cite news | last = Bell | first = Alex | title = Plans to turn former Granada Studios site into St John's Quarter submitted | url = http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/business/plans-turn-former-granada-studios-9551160 | work = [[Manchester Evening News]] | publisher= [[Trinity Mirror]] | date = 30 June 2015 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> * [[Manchester Civil Justice Centre|Civil Justice Centre]]<ref name="Observer_211007">{{cite news | last = Bayley | first = Stephen | author-link = Stephen Bayley | title = Architecture: What a perfect place to get divorced | url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2007/oct/21/architecture | work = [[The Observer]] | publisher= [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 21 October 2007 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> * [[Spinningfields#Present day|Spinningfields]]<ref name="MEN_100614">{{cite news | last = Jupp | first = Adam | title = Allied London in £15m loan boost | url = http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/business/allied-london-15m-loan-boost-7247720 | work = [[Manchester Evening News]] | publisher= [[Trinity Mirror]] | date = 10 June 2014 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> :* Hardman Square :* 3 Hardman Street :* The Lawns :* The Avenue :* The Avenue North :* Tower 12 :* Leftbank
=== Leeds === [[File:Clarence Dock 1.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Leeds Dock]]]] * [[Leeds Dock]]<ref name="Yorks_020614">{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Dawn of colourful new era for Leeds’s Clarence Dock | url = http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/news/latest-news/top-stories/dawn-of-colourful-new-era-for-leeds-s-clarence-dock-1-6648365 | work = [[Yorkshire Evening Post]] | publisher= [[Johnston Press]] | date = 2 June 2014 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref>
=== London === * Aldersgate<ref name="PW_170513">{{cite news | last = Johnstone | first = Nick | title = Agents instructed on £200m City sale | url = http://www.propertyweek.com/agents-instructed-on-%C2%A3200m-city-sale/5054900.article | work = [[Property Week]] | publisher= Metropolis International | date = 17 May 2013 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> * [[Brunswick Centre|The Brunswick]]<ref name="HL_2014">{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = The Brunswick, Camden | url = http://hidden-london.com/gazetteer/brunswick/ | work = Hidden London | publisher= [[Daily Gazetteer]] | date = 2014 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> * 20 [[Cannon Street]]<ref name="CoStar_200212">{{cite web | last = Norman | first = Paul | title = Allied London set to prelet City HQ to headhunter | url = http://www.costar.co.uk/en/assets/news/2012/February/Allied-London-set-to-prelet-City-HQ-to-headhunter/ | website = costar.co.uk | publisher= [[CoStar Group]] | date = 20 February 2012 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> * [[Poplar, London|Poplar Village]]<ref name="PR_180512">{{cite news | last = Lewis | first = Warren | title = United House and Allied London chosen for £100m new look for Poplar | url = http://www.propertyreporter.co.uk/landlords/united-house-and-allied-london-chosen-for-100m-new-look-for-poplar.html | work = Property Reporter | publisher= Barcadia Media | date = 18 May 2012 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> * Herbal House<ref name="BD_121114">{{cite news | last = Graham | first = James | title = Allied London wins consent for former Mirror print centre | url = http://www.thebusinessdesk.com/northwest/news/692118-allied-london-wins-consent-for-former-mirror-print-centre.html | work = The Business Desk | date = 12 November 2014 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref> * 28 Savile Row<ref name="PW_211211">{{cite news | last = Stewart | first = Sarah | title = Great Portland Estates sells in Savile Row | url = http://www.propertyweek.com/great-portland-estates-sells-in-savile-row/5029785.article | work = [[Property Week]] | publisher= Metropolis International | date = 21 December 2011 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref>
=== Glasgow === * Skypark<ref name="Herald_080600">{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Expansion at Skypark | url = http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12196072.Expansion_at_Skypark/ | work = [[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] | publisher= Herald & Times Group | date = 8 June 2000 | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref>
== The ''hello'' Project == In April 2014 Allied London launched ''hello'' Work, to provide hot desking, co-working and studios alongside a community and events programme for [[Small and medium-sized enterprises|SME]]s.<ref name="SME_club">{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Start-ups say hello to growth | url = http://www.smeclubmanchester.com/start-ups-say-hello-to-growth/ | website = smeclubmanchester.com | publisher= SME Club Manchester | accessdate = 5 October 2015 }}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=September 2016}} {{COI|date=September 2016}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Alona Barkat |image = Alona-Barkat-001.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1969|6|24|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Ashkelon]], Israel |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |residence = [[Tel Aviv]], Israel |nationality = Israeli |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = Owner of [[Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.|Hapoel Be'er Sheva]] |education = |alma_mater = [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] |employer = |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = [[Ashkelon]] |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Eli Barkat |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = [[Nir Barkat]] (brother-in-law) |callsign = |awards = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }}
'''Alona Barkat''' ({{lang-he-n|אלונה ברקת}}; born 24 June 1969) is an Israeli [[Businessperson|businesswoman]], and owner of the [[Association football|football]] team [[Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.|Hapoel Beer Sheva]].
==Biography== Barkat was born and raised in [[Ashkelon]], Israel.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Jerusalem-Report/A-victory-for-social-change-457475 A victory for social change - ''The Jerusalem Post''<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> At the age of 14 she moved to [[Jerusalem]] to {{what|study [[atelier]]|date=January 2018}}. Four years later she returned to national service in her hometown. She then studied at [[The Hebrew University of Jerusalem]],<ref name=autogenerated1>[https://www.thejc.com/news/israel/hapoel-beersheva-becomes-israel-s-leicester-city-1.57639 "Hapoel Beersheva becomes Israel's Leicester City"]</ref> performing undergraduate and graduate studies in the history of the [[Middle East]]. During her studies she met Eli Barkat,<ref name=autogenerated1 /> then a student in Mathematics and Computer Science, and the two married.
In 1996 she moved to [[Silicon Valley]] in the United States with her husband, who became a businessman with his brother [[Nir Barkat]]. He was an early investor in [[Check Point]] and set up the [[venture capital]] fund BRM and IVN. In the eight years in which the family lived in the United States, Barkat started in the field of philanthropy. Among other things, the fund management company IVN also funded social projects, and has been active in organizations such as [[AIPAC]] and the [[Jewish Federation]] of [[San Francisco]].
In 2004, she moved back to Israel with her family. Relations with the businessman Lonnie Herzikovic, then-owner of the football team [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]], led her to consider entering a partnership with Maccabi Tel Aviv. She was involved in establishing a research institute at the [[University of Tel Aviv]], together with the Rashi Foundation, where she met [[Eli Alaluf]], CEO of the Fund at the time. Alaluf convinced her to buy the football team [[Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.|Hapoel Beer Sheva]], which played in the second division at the time.
In the summer of 2007, just weeks before the opening of the season, the acquisition of the group from the previous owner, Eli Zino, was completed. Barkat became the first woman in Israel to own a football team.<ref>{{he icon}} {{cite web|title=Obstacles have been removed, Alona Barkat Hapoel Be'er Sheva acquired|url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3421188,00.html|website=Ynet|accessdate=4 July 2007}}</ref> Barkat's management team put special emphasis on a youth department, educational activities, and community connection. In March 2010, the group announced their departure at the end of the season, after a number of fans of the group tried to attack the coach, [[Guy Azouri]]. Two months later, after seeing a dramatic improvement in fan behavior, she announced that she had changed her mind and that she intended to stay with the group.
In May 2016 the team won the [[2015–16 Israeli Premier League|Football League Championship]] in football.<ref>{{he icon}} {{cite web|title=After 40 years: Hapoel Beer Sheva has won the state championship with a 1-3 for Bnei Sakhnin|url=http://sports.walla.co.il/item/2963216|website=WallaSport|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
Barkat lives with her husband and three children in [[Tel Aviv]], Israel.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barkat, Alona}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Israeli businesspeople]] [[Category:Israeli women in business]] [[Category:Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.]] [[Category:Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox company | name = Amfac, Inc. | logo = | type = Public company |trading_name=Kaanapali Land, LLC |traded_as=({{OTC Pink|KANP}}) | industry = [[Land development]] | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = 1849 as H. Hackfeld and Company | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = [[Hawaii]] | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} {{Big Five Hawaii}} '''Amfac, Inc.''', formerly known as '''American Factors''' and originally '''H. Hackfeld and Company''', was a [[land development]] company in Hawaii. Founded in 1849 as a retail and sugar business, it was considered one of the so-called [[Big Five (Hawaii)|Big Five]] companies in the [[Territory of Hawaii]]. At its peak it owned {{convert|60000|acre}} of land, and was a dominant sugar company in Hawaii as well the founder of one of its best known department stores, [[Liberty House (US)|Liberty House]]. It now<!-- when? --> owns {{convert|5000|acre}} of land in [[Kaanapali]] on the island of [[Maui]]. Since 2005 it is known as Kaanapali Land, LLC ({{OTC Pink|KANP}}).
==History==
German immigrant Heinrich Hackfeld and his brother-in-law J. C. Pflueger founded a dry goods store called H. Hackfeld and Company in 1849 in [[Honolulu]]. Hackfeld later<!-- when?? --> became the business agent for [[Old Sugar Mill of Koloa|Kōloa Plantation]] on the island of [[Kauai|Kaua{{okina}}i]]. [[Paul Isenberg]] (1837–1903) became a partner in 1881.<ref>{{cite book |title= The Story of Hawaii and Its Builders |year=1925 |publisher=[[Honolulu Star Bulletin]] |editor= George F. Nellist |url= http://files.usgwarchives.net/hi/statewide/bios/isenberg34bs.txt |chapter= Isenberg, Paul |accessdate=August 5, 2010 }}</ref>
During [[World War I]], Pioneer Mill, DCCA #207, was seized by the U.S. government [[Alien Property Custodian]]. It was later sold to a consortium of Hawaii businessmen in 1918, who changed the name to "American Factors". In 1966, the name was further shortened to "Amfac". Henry Alexander Walker became president in the 1930s. The family estate known as the [[H. Alexander Walker Residence]], was developed into a showcase garden.<ref name="focus">{{cite web |title= H. Alexander Walker Residence nomination form |author=Dorothy Riconda |author2= Robert M. Fox |work=National Register of Historic Places |date= September 18, 1972 |publisher=U.S. National Park Service |url= {{NRHP url|id=73000665}} |accessdate=June 27, 2010 }}</ref>
From 1968 to 1972 under president Henry Alexander Walker Jr. Amfac acquired 42 different companies.<ref>{{cite news |date= July 31, 1972 |title= Corporations:Amfac's Wide Swing |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,877962,00.html |work=TIME |accessdate=June 27, 2010 }}</ref>
Ronald L. Sloan was removed as president November 20, 1987 and replaced by Richard L. Griffith (Walker was still chairman of the board). The company announced it was selling its non-Hawaii business units.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/14/business/amfac-is-planning-to-sell-its-non-hawaii-businesses.html |date= December 14, 1987 |title= Amfac Is Planning to Sell Its Non-Hawaii Businesses |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=June 27, 2010 | first=Calvin | last=Sims}}</ref> Amfac was bought by [[Chicago]]-based [[JMB Realty]] in 1988 for US$920 million.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1988/11/19/business/company-news-amfac-holders-back-bid-by-jmb.html |date= November 11, 1988 |title= Company News: Amfac Holders Back Bid by JMB |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=June 27, 2010 }}</ref> As the sugar industry in Hawaii declined after statehood, so did the fortunes of Amfac. Amfac's assets were gradually sold off or closed. Oahu Sugar in [[Waipahu]] was closed in 1994.<ref name="dynasty">{{Cite web| title = Dynasty in decline: Amfac, the first Hawaii company to earn $1 billion in revenue, is a shadow of its former self| work = Honolulu Star-Bulletin| accessdate = 2018-04-22| date = 2001-09-02| url = http://archives.starbulletin.com/2001/09/02/business/index.html}}</ref> Liberty House went into bankruptcy in 1998 (it was later acquired by [[Federated Department Stores]] and now carries the [[Macy's]] brand name). The Pioneer Mill in [[Lahaina, Hawaii|Lahaina]] closed in 1999, and the [[Kekaha, Hawaii|Kekaha]] Sugar Mill and [[Lihue, Hawaii|Lihue]] Plantation closed in 2000.<ref>{{Cite web| last = Young| first = Peter T.| title = Ho‘okuleana: Pioneer Mill| work = Ho‘okuleana| accessdate = 2018-04-22| date = 2013-08-02| url = http://totakeresponsibility.blogspot.com/2013/08/pioneer-mill.html}}</ref><ref name="dynasty"/> Amfac Hawaii went into [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] in 2002.<ref>[http://archives.starbulletin.com/2002/02/28/news/index.html Amfac mired in debt]. ''[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]]''.</ref> Amfac Hotels & Resorts was retained by JMB and was renamed [[Xanterra Parks and Resorts]]. Amfac Hawaii was reorganized as Kaanapali Land, LLC and the bankruptcy closed in 2005.<ref>{{cite web |title= Annual Report (form 10K) of Kaanapali Land, LLC |date= March 29, 2010 |work=US Securities and Exchange Commission EDGAR |url= https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1230058/000089262610000036/kaa_k09.txt |accessdate=June 27, 2010 }}</ref> Some of the former plantation land uphill from the resort has been subdivided into a development called Kāʻanapali Coffee Farms.<ref>{{cite web|title=Welcome to the New Family Farm |work=Kāʻanapali Coffee Farms web site |url=http://www.kaanapalicoffeefarms.com/farms/farms.html |accessdate=June 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100909062834/http://www.kaanapalicoffeefarms.com/farms/farms.html |archivedate=September 9, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref>
==See also== *[[History of sugar]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |title= Kamaaina – A century in Hawaii |author=William A. Simonds |others= Keichi Kimura, illustrator |date= October 1, 1949 |publisher=American Factors, Limited |url= https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&docId=920122 }}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040324102128/http://kaanapalidevelopment.com/ Kaanapali Land Management Corp.], principal subsidiary of Kaanapali Land {{Hawaii}}
[[Category:Business in Hawaii]] [[Category:Real estate companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Hawaii]] [[Category:Defunct companies based in Hawaii]] [[Category:History of sugar]] [[Category:1849 establishments in Hawaii]] [[Category:Companies established in 1849]]

revision.comment: /* External links */ fmt
revision.text:
{{For|Dalhousie Square in Montreal|Dalhousie Station (Montreal)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2018}} [[File:Kolkata BBD Bagh2.jpg|thumb|350px|right|Writers' Building from across [[Lal Dighi]] in B.B.D. Bagh]] '''B.B.D. Bagh''', formerly called '''Dalhousie Square''', is the shortened version for Benoy-Badal-Dinesh Bagh. It is the seat of power of the state government, as well as the [[central business district]] in [[Kolkata]] in [[Kolkata district]] in the [[India]]n [[States and territories of India|state]] of [[West Bengal]].
==Origin of name== [[File:Memory_of_martyrdom.jpg|thumb|Memory of martyrdom]] {{Benoy Badal Dinesh}} B.B.D. stands for three young [[Indian independence freedom fighters]] — [[Benoy Basu|Benoy]], [[Badal Gupta|Badal]] and [[Dinesh Gupta|Dinesh]] — who on 8 December 1930 shot dead the Inspector General of Prisons, N.S. Simpson, in the balconies of the [[Writers' Building]] of the then Dalhousie Square. The square had been named after [[James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie|Lord Dalhousie]], [[Governor General of India]] from 1847 to 1856. At different times it has been called ‘The Green before the Fort’ or Tank Square.<ref>Cotton, H.E.A., ''Calcutta Old and New'', 1909/1980, p 268-9, General Printers and Publishers Pvt. Ltd.</ref>
{{quote box|width=300px|quote=As we enter the town, very expansive square opens before us, with a large expanse of water in the middle, for public use… the square itself is composed of magnificent houses which render Calcutta not only the handsomest town in Asia but one of the finest in the world. One side of the square consists of a range of buildings occupied by persons in civil employments under the Company, such as writers in public offices.<ref>Quoted by Bhattacharya, Sabyasachi, ''Traders and Trades in Old Calcutta'', in ''Calcutta, the Living City'', Vol I, pp. 156-160, edited by Sukanta Chaudhuri, Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0-19-563696-1}}.</ref>|source= [[Louis de Grandpré|L. de Grandpre]], ''A Voyage in the Indian Ocean and to Bengal'' (1803)}}
==Geography== The B.B.D. Bagh area is near the [[Hooghly River]] in the western part of central [[Kolkata]] and is a square built around the old [[Lal Dighi]] tank. The old fort built by the British was near where the General Post Office now is. The area was in the heart of [[Kalikata]] or the White Town in old Calcutta.
==History==
[[File:Dalhousie 1870s.jpg|thumbnail|left|A picture of Dalhousie Square looking northeast in the 1870s ]] [[File:General Post Office (GPO), Calcutta (c. 1880s).jpg|thumbnail|right|A view of the General Post Office in the 1880s]] B.B.D. Bagh (or Dalhousie Square as it was formerly known) was created as the center of the [[British East India Company|British East India Company's]] trading post along the banks of the Hooghly River. Between the river and the tank (now known as [[Lal Dighi]]), lay the original Fort William. In the summer of 1756, [[Siraj ud-Daulah|Nawab Siraj ud-Daulah]] of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa launched an attack on the British town for the company's decision to strengthen the fortifications around it. The survivors of the attack were sent to a garrison within the fort which spurred an incident infamously known as the [[Black Hole of Calcutta]]. The British soon retook the city after the Nawab retreated from the forces of [[Robert Clive]]. Within a year, the British East India Company's forces had taken all of Bengal and Calcutta, along with the square, was established as the commercial and political center of [[British India]].
Over the next one and a half centuries, the square grew in importance and influence. It was named after [[Lord Dalhousie]], the Governor-General of India. After the fall of company rule in India, the Writers' Building became the secretariat of the Viceroy of India. A number of corporations and institutions opened offices and headquarters in and around the square, giving it its role as the central business district of the city. In 1912, the capital of British India was officially moved to [[New Delhi]], but the majority of the financial and political institutions in the area remained.
During the first half of the 20th century, the [[Indian Independence Movement]] began to reach its peak and took a violent turn in Bengal. On the eighth of December 1930, three revolutionaries, Benoy, Badal, and Dinesh, stormed the building and fatally shot the Inspector General of Prisons, N.S. Simpson. The three committed suicide and the square was renamed B.B.D. Bagh in their honor after Indian independence. In 1947, the political establishments were officially handed over to the government of India and the government of the newly formed state of [[West Bengal]]. Over the next few decades, Calcutta (as it was known) would go through rapid economic decline, but B.B.D. Bagh would remain the heart of East India.
==Modern significance== [[File:BBD_Bag_Station.jpg|thumb|BBD Bag circular railway station. Kolkata]] [[File:Calcutta GPO 2010-08-29.jpg|thumbnail|right|A view of the General Post Office in 2010]] [[File:The Royal Insurance Building, Kolkata, West Bengal.jpg|thumb|The Royal Insurance Building, Kolkata, West Bengal]] [[File:Central Telegraph Office - Red Cross Place - Kolkata 2011-12-18 0166.JPG|thumbnail|left|The Central Telegraph Office which lies to the south of the main square.]] [[File:KolkataHSBC.JPG|thumbnail|right|Hong Kong House which has and still houses the offices of HSBC in Kolkata.]] B.B.D. Bagh is still the commercial and political center of all of East India and many of the business and political institutions from the colonial era still exist. The centerpiece is the [[Writers' Building]] which is the secretariat of the Government of the State of West Bengal and houses the office of the [[Chief Minister of West Bengal]]. To the west lie the [[General Post Office, Kolkata|General Post Office]], the Royal Insurance Building, the eastern office of the [[Reserve Bank of India]], the headquarters of the [[Eastern Railway zone|Eastern Railway]], head office of the [[Kolkata Port Trust]], and a number of other government offices. The native name of the area is '<nowiki/>''Office Para'''. To the north lie the Royal Exchange Building which houses the [[Bengal Chamber of Commerce and Industry]], the [[Calcutta Stock Exchange]], the [[Standard Chartered]] Building, and many financial establishments. The eastern end also houses a number of offices till [[Chittaranjan Avenue]]. The area south of the square is home to the [[Raj Bhavan (West Bengal)|Raj Bhavan]], which is now the residence of the governor and the former residence of the viceroy and governor-general of India. A number of former British colonial administrative offices, including the former foreign and military secretariats, the Treasury Office, the Telegraph Office, and the [[Kolkata Town Hall]] can be found here. This area is also a major commercial district with the offices of [[HSBC]] at Hong Kong House and the [[Great Eastern Hotel (Kolkata)|Great Eastern Hotel]].
B.B.D. Bagh can still be considered as one of the best remnants and concentrated zones of British colonial architecture in the world. The square is also characterized by other historical landmarks including [[St. John's Church, Kolkata|St. John's Church]], which was one of the first buildings in Calcutta and is modeled on [[St. Martin-in-the-Fields]] in London's Trafalgar Square. The church is home to beautiful stained glass windows and paintings as well as the mausoleum of [[Job Charnock]], the man who founded modern Calcutta. B.B.D. Bagh also has a statue of famous philanthropist [[Maharaja Lakshmeshwar Singh]] of [[Raj Darbhanga|Darbhanga]] (1858–1898), sculpted by [[Edward Onslow Ford]].
Overall, the square sees thousands of people arriving from all over the [[Kolkata metropolitan area]] to the offices and businesses that have characterized the area for the last three centuries since the establishment of Calcutta.
==Preservation==
Dalhousie Square was included in the [[2004 World Monuments Watch|2004]] and [[2006 World Monuments Watch]] by the [[World Monuments Fund]] due to "decades of neglect".<ref>[http://www.wmf.org/project/dalhousie-square World Monuments Fund - Dalhousie Square]</ref> After this listing the international financial services company [[American Express]] provided funding through WMF for the square's preservation. A number of buildings in the area have also been listed as heritage buildings and have gone through extensive restorations to bring back the charm of the square. The centerpiece, the Writers' Building, has been temporarily vacated to give way for a massive restoration of the building, which has fallen into disrepair in many areas.
==References== {{reflist}}

Bagh), Calcutta in 1910 image:Kolkata BBD statues.jpg|Statues of Benoy, Badal and Dinesh in front of Writers' Building image:Kolkata BBD Bagh1.jpg|General Post Office and Reserve Bank of India building from across Lal Dighi image:Kolkata BBD Bagh3.jpg|The southern side of B.B.D. Bagh image:GPO, KOLKATA.jpg| Dome of GPO from across Lal Dighi image:Maharaja Lakshmeshwar Singh statue - Kolkata.JPG|Statue of Maharaja Lakshmeshwar Singh image:Facade of Writers Building - Central Kolkata.jpg|The facade of the Writers' Building image:Town Hall - Kolkata 2011-12-18 0335.JPG|The Kolkata Town Hall image:Calcutta High Court.jpg|The Calcutta High Court image:Old Koilaghat Building - Kolkata 2012-09-22 0303.JPG|The old Koilaghat Building of the Eastern Railway image:Samriddhi Bhavan - Strand Road - Kolkata 2012-09-22 0343.JPG|The eastern offices of the State Bank of India image:Strand Road - Kolkata 2012-09-22 0339.JPG|A view of Strand Road and a government administrative building image:Currency Building - Dalhousie Square - Kolkata 2012-09-22 0289.JPG|The Currency Building undergoing renovations and restorations image:South-east Crossing - Dalhousie Square - Kolkata 2012-09-22 0286.JPG|The southeastern corner of the main square image:St Andrew's Church - Dalhousie Square - Kolkata 2012-09-22 0281.JPG|St. Andrew's Church in the center of the square image:Netaji Subhas Road - Dalhousie Square - Kolkata 2012-10-09 0296.JPG|Netaji Subhas Road (formerly Clive Road) which runs along the eastern side of Lal Dighi image:Dalhousie Square South - Kolkata 2011-12-18 0130.JPG|A view down Dalhousie Square South </gallery> </center>

{{distinguish|BTS Group Holdings}} {{buzzword|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = | type = [[Public company|Public]] ({{OMX|SSE13288|BTS B}}) | logo = BTS Group logo.jpg | logo_size = 220px | foundation = 1986 as '''B'''usiness '''T'''raining '''S'''ystems AB | founder = [[Henrik Ekelund]] | location = [[Stockholm, Sweden]] | locations = 34 | industry = Professional Services | services = Strategy Execution
Business Acumen
Leadership Development
Assessment Centers
Sales Force Transformation
Innovation | area_served = Worldwide | homepage = {{Official website|http://www.bts.com/}} }} '''BTS Group AB''' ('''BTS''') is a global strategy implementation consulting firm founded in 1986. The company provides strategy alignment and execution consulting services and designs customized business simulations, digital technology, and assessments to develop business acumen, leadership, and sales capabilities.{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=BTSB:SS |title=BTS Group Ab-B Shares (BTSB:Stockholm) |publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek |date= |accessdate=2014-08-30}} BTS has several practice areas - Strategy Execution, Business Acumen, Leadership Development, Sales Training, Innovation, Coaching and Assessments.{{cite web|url=http://www.bts.com/what-we-do |title=BTS Group AB (BTSb.ST) |publisher= TS |date= |accessdate=2015-09-09}} The company serves banking, biotech and pharmaceutical, consumer products, insurance, manufacturing, oil and gas, professional services, retail, technology, and telecommunications sectors.{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=BTSB:SS |title=BTS Group Ab-B Shares (BTSB:Stockholm) |publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek |date= |accessdate=2014-09-04}} Headquartered in [[Stockholm, Sweden]], the firm has over 600 employees across 34 global offices. The company's client base is spread across 53 countries and includes 60 of the U.S. Fortune 100 and over 30 of the Global Fortune 100.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasdaqomxnordic.com/aktier/microsite?Instrument=SSE13288&name=BTS%20Group%20B |title=BTS B, BTS GROUP B, (SE0000805426) |publisher=NASDAQ OMX (Nordic) |accessdate=2014-08-30}} BTS customers include companies such as [[Accenture]], Aetna, [[Unilever]], [[AT&T]], Chevron, [[Coca-Cola]], [[Ericsson]], Google, GSK, [[Telstra]], HSBC, [[Hewlett-Packard]], Mondelez, Salesforce.com, Sodexo, [[Toyota]], and others.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/overview?symbol=BTSb.ST |title=BTS Group AB (BTSb.ST) |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2014-08-30}} BTS is a public company listed on the [[NASDAQ]]-[[OMX]] Stockholm trading under the symbol BTS B.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasdaqomxnordic.com/shares/microsite?Instrument=SSE13288 |title=NASDAQ OMX (Nordic) |publisher=NASDAQ |date= |accessdate=2014-08-19}} == Organizational History == [[File:Henrik-Ekelund.jpg|BTS CEO and founder, Henrik Ekelund|thumb|right|205px]]BTS was founded in 1986 by [[Henrik Ekelund]], current President and Chief Executive Officer, with the support of three investors from one of Scandinavia’s prominent strategic consulting firms. The firm focused on supporting clients’ efforts to implement strategy by focusing on the human capital part of the execution equation.{{cite web|title=Hög tid att utse|url=http://www.bts.com/docs/press/ekelund-degans-industri-article.pdf?sfvrsn=2|publisher=BTS Group}} In February 2005, BTS acquired Strategic Management Group, Inc. (SMG). The acquisition enabled the firm to create a broader base for future organic growth and deepen its expertise. In September 2006, BTS acquired The Real Learning Company (RLC) and Advantage Performance Group, Inc. (APG).{{cite web |title=BTS Group AB Has Completed the Acquisition of The Advantage Performance Group and The Real Learning Company |url=http://markets.financialcontent.com/stocks/news/read?GUID=243657 |publisher=Financial Content |access-date=2014-08-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826113546/http://markets.financialcontent.com/stocks/news/read?GUID=243657 |archive-date=2014-08-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The acquisitions consolidated a highly fragmented market and expanded the company's existing sales and leadership programs. In July 2013, BTS acquired Wizer A/S to expand the firm's digital capabilities and compliment its existing portfolio.{{cite web|title=BTS Group AB (BTSb.ST) |url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/overview?symbol=BTSb.ST | publisher=Reuters}} In October 2014, BTS acquired Fenestra Inc., a global provider of premier technology-enhanced assessment and leadership development centers and [[solution]]s.{{Cite web|title = BTS Group AB acquires all the businesses of Fenestra, Inc.|url = http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2014/10/17/674012/0/en/BTS-Group-AB-acquires-all-the-businesses-of-Fenestra-Inc.html|website = GlobeNewswire News Room|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} In March 2015, BTS acquired AVO Vision, a South African-based company focused on corporate learning and development as well as community-worksite education. The acquisition expanded the firm's global reach and expertise in the leadership development sphere as AVO Vision's core offerings focused on leadership, management, self-mastery, and sales execution skills.{{Cite web|title = BTS has Acquired a Leading South African Learning & Development Company|url = http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2015/03/26/718930/0/en/BTS-has-Acquired-a-Leading-South-African-Learning-Development-Company.html|website = globenewswire.com|accessdate = 2015-03-26}} In 2016, BTS Group acquired Cesim Italia Srl and Design Innovation Srl based in Milan, Italy to strengthen its Southern European position.{{Cite web|title = BTS buys two Italian companies|url = https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/BTSb.ST/key-developments/article/3400925|website = reuters.com|accessdate = 2016-07-06}} In September 2015, BTS launched a new brand, logo, tagline ("Strategy made personal") and website, designed in partnership with UK-based [http://saffron-consultants.com/ Saffron Brand Consultants].{{Cite web|title = Strategy made personal|url = http://www.bts.com/news-insights/strategy-execution-blog/strategy-execution/2015/09/15/bts-brand-has-evolved|website = www.bts.com|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} == Services == BTS supports executive management in the areas of strategy transformation, business and financial decision-making, key performance indicator alignment, merger integration, cross business-unit collaboration, innovation and customer understanding and relations.{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=BTSB:SS |title=BTS GROUP AB-B SHARES (BTSB:SS): Stock Quote & Company Profile |publisher=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date= |accessdate=2014-08-19}} Client engagement teams typically consist of a combination of industry experts, capability specialists and professionals with local market knowledge. The company helps organizations in the implementation of change and the improvement of profitability through the following practice areas: * Strategy Execution * [[Business Acumen]] * [[Leadership Development]] * Sales Force Transformation * Coaching *Assessment Centers *Innovation == Global Structure == * North America: [[New York City]], New York; [[Stamford, Connecticut]]; [[Chicago]], Illinois; [[Austin, Texas]]; [[Scottsdale, Arizona]]; [[Los Angeles]], California; [[San Francisco]], California; * Europe: [[Helsinki]], Finland; [[Stockholm]], Sweden; [[Munich]], Germany; [[Amsterdam]], Netherlands; [[Brussels]], Belgium; [[Paris]], France; [[London]], England; [[Bilbao, Spain]], [[Madrid]], Spain; [[Rome]], Italy * Middle East: [[Dubai]], United Arab Emirates * Asia: [[Bangalore]], India; [[Mumbai]], India; [[Bangkok]], Thailand; [[Shanghai]], China; [[Seoul]], South Korea; [[Singapore]]; [[Taipei]], Taiwan; [[Tokyo]], Japan * Central and South America: [[Mexico City]], Mexico; [[Sao Paulo]], Brazil * Australia: [[Sydney]], Australia; [[Melbourne]], Australia * Africa: [[Johannesburg]], South Africa == Awards, Honors & Publications == In 2017, BTS was named a Top 20 Leadership Training Company by [http://www.trainingindustry.com/ Training Industry].{{Cite web|url=http://www.trainingindustry.com/leadership/top-companies-listings/2017/2017-top-20-leadership-training-companies-list.aspx|title=2017 Top 20 Leadership Training Companies List {{!}} Training Industry|website=www.trainingindustry.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-24}} The media publication also recognized BTS in 2016 as a Leadership Training Company to Watch and a Top 20 Sales Training Company.{{Cite web|url=http://www.trainingindustry.com/leadership/top-companies-listings/2016/2016-leadership-training-companies-watch-list.aspx|title=2016 Leadership Training Companies Watch List {{!}} Training Industry|website=www.trainingindustry.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-24}} In 2015, Training Industry listed BTS as one of the top 20 Sales Training Organizations.{{cite web|url=http://www.trainingindustry.com/sales-training/top-company-listings/2015/2015-top-20-sales-training-companies.aspx|title=2015 Sales Training Companies Watch List|publisher=Training Industry}} In 2014, BTS was named a Top 20 Sales Training Organizations and one of the Top 20 Gamification Companies.{{cite web|url=http://www.trainingindustry.com/sales-training/top-company-listings/2014/2014-top-20-sales-training-companies.aspx|title=2014 Top 20 Leadership Training Companies|publisher=Training Industry}} In 2013, BTS was acknowledged by Training Industry as one of the top 20 Leadership Development companies for the second year in a row.{{cite web|title=2013 Top 20 Leadership Training Companies |url=http://www.trainingindustry.com/leadership/top-companies-listings/2013/2013-top-20-leadership-training-companies.aspx|publisher=Training Industry}} In 2016, BTS received two [http://www.brandonhall.com/excellenceawards/ Brandon Hall Awards] for client partnerships - a Gold with Intuit for the Best Unique or Innovative Leadership Development Program, and a Silver with MetLife for the Best Advance in Assessment Utilization to Guide Talent Decisions Category.{{Cite web|url=http://www.brandonhall.com/excellenceawards/past-winners.php|title=Past Winners|website=www.brandonhall.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-24}} BTS received a Silver 2013 Brandon Hall Group Excellence in Learning Award for their partnership with [[AT&T]] to create the AT&T Sales and Service Center Simulation.{{cite web|title=Winners of the 2013 Brandon Hall Group Excellence in Learning Awards |url=http://brandonhall.com/excellence-learning.php?year=2013|publisher=Brandon Hall Group}} BTS client [[Newell Rubbermaid]] was awarded Sales Training Program of the Year by [[Stevie Awards]] for their customized [[solution]].{{cite web|title=2011 Stevie Awards for Sales & Customer Service|url=http://www.stevieawards.com/pubs/sales/awards/426_2281_20877.cfm?fromMobileSite=1|publisher=Stevie Awards}} BTS Asia Pacific received a 2016 HR Vendors of the Year Award, hosted by Human Resources Magazine, in the Best Leadership Development Consultant Category.{{Cite news|url=http://www.humanresourcesonline.net/events/winners-photos-hr-vendors-year-2016-singapore/|title=Winners and photos: HR Vendors of the Year 2016, Singapore|date=2016-11-25|newspaper=Human Resources Online|access-date=2017-02-24|language=en-US}} ==Sponsorship== Since 2010, BTS USA has partnered with [[Rainforest Trust]] on sustainability campaigns to preserve threatened rainforests. In 2015, BTS sponsored the second round of the Rainforest Trust #SkiptoSave campaign supporting Rainforest Trust's 2020 Initiative designed to protect 20 million acres of rainforest by 2020.{{cite web|title=Consulting Firm Teams with Rainforest Trust to Save Tropical Forest|url=https://www.rainforesttrust.org/news/bts-usa-saves-colombian-rainforest/|publisher=Rainforest Trust}} In partnership with the Sparkassesntiftung fur international Kooperation (Savings Banks Foundation for International Cooperation), BTS has created a business simulation program to teach business and financial acumen in developing nations.{{cite web|title=Annual Report 2009|url=http://www.sparkassenstiftung.de/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/Jahresberichte/JB_2009_E.pdf/|publisher=Finanzgruppe Sparkassenstiftung fur international Kooperation}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} As of June 2015, such programs had been held for more than 10,000 participants in 12 countries. ==Management== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Name !! Position |- | [[Henrik Ekelund]] || President and Chief Executive Officer |- | Michael Grindfors || Independent Chairman of the Board of Directors |- | Stefan Brown || Chief Financial Officer |- | Stefan Hellberg || Executive Vice President, Head of Sales and Human Resources |- | Jessica Parisi || Chief Executive Officer and President BTS USA |- | Rommin Adl || Executive Vice President, Head of Global Marketing{{cite web|title=StrategyDriven Professional Podcast Episode 4 – Skills Mismatch: Business Acumen and Strategy Execution |url=http://www.strategydriven.com/2013/04/25/strategydriven-professional-podcast-episode-4-skills-mismatch-business-acumen-and-strategy-execution/|publisher=StrategyDriven}} |- | Todd Ehrlich || Executive Vice President, Head of Development Processes and Chief Operating Officer BTS USA |- | Philios Andreou || Executive Vice President, Head of Southern Europe and Latin America |- | Dan Parisi || Executive Vice President, Head of Strategic Alignment & Business Acumen Practice {{cite web|title=StrategyDriven Podcast Episode 46 – Your Leadership Off-Site is Wasting a Lot of People’s Time |url=http://www.strategydriven.com/2013/10/31/strategydriven-podcast-episode-46-strategic-planning-leadership-site-wasting-lot-peoples-time/|publisher=StrategyDriven}} |- | Peter Mulford || Executive Vice President, Head of the Innovation Practice |- | Lou Schachter || Executive Vice President, Global Head of the BTS Sales Practice{{cite web|title=StrategyDriven Podcast Episode 45 – Marketing & Sales: Closing the Value Gap |url=http://www.strategydriven.com/2013/07/11/strategydriven-podcast-episode-45-marketing-sales-closing-the-value-gap/|publisher=StrategyDriven}} |- | Thomas Ahlerup || Senior Vice President, Head of Corporate Communications and Investor Relations |} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{Official website}}
