'''Beny Steinmetz''' ({{lang-he|בני שטיינמץ}}; born 1956) is an Israeli businessman, with a [[Portfolio (finance)|portfolio]] in diamond-mining, engineering and real estate.<ref name="forbes2010"/><ref name="haaretz">Michael Rochvarger, [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/hapoalim-confronts-beny-steinmetz-1.290077 "Hapoalim confronts Beny Steinmetz"], ''[[Haaretz]]'', 13 May 2010.</ref><ref name="BSG Resources Limited">[http://www.bsgresources.com/about/ BSG Resources Limited About] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406160542/http://www.bsgresources.com/about|date=6 April 2013|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref>
==Biography== Beny Steinmetz was born in [[Netanya]], the fourth child of Rubin Steinmetz.<ref name=Guardian_01>{{cite web|last=Sherwood|first=Harriet|title=Beny Steinmetz: Israeli diamond dealer who likes to keep a low profile|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/jul/30/beny-steinmetz-international-israeli-profile|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Media Group|accessdate=30 July 2013}}</ref> He inherited the [[Geneva, Switzerland|Geneva]]-based Steinmetz Diamond Group from his father.<ref name="forbes2010">[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/10/billionaires-2010_Beny-Steinmetz_N65G.html Forbes 2010]</ref> Steinmetz lives in [[Geneva, Switzerland|Geneva]].<ref name="nyer2013">Patrick Radden Keefe, [http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/07/08/130708fa_fact_keefe?currentPage=all "Buried Secrets: How an Israeli billionaire wrested control of one of Africa's biggest prizes"], ''The New Yorker'', 8 July 2013.</ref>
Steinmetz is married with four children.<ref name="forbes2010"/> With his wife, he oversees the Beny & Agnes Steinmetz Foundation, which donates to schools, hospitals, army units and the arts in Israel.<ref name="forbes2010"/> He also holds French citizenship and describes himself as an "international Israeli."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/jul/30/beny-steinmetz-international-israeli-profile|title=Beny Steinmetz: Israeli diamond dealer who likes to keep a low profile|publisher=The Guardian|date=29 July 2013}}</ref>
==Business career== Steinmetz along with his brother Daniel founded what subsequently became known as Beny Steinmetz Group Resources (BSGR). Beny currently occupies an advisory role to the company's Board of Directors.<ref name="BSG Resources Limited"/>
In March 2014, the Swiss daily ''[[Le Temps]]'' reported that Beny Steinmetz had sold shares in the Steinmetz Diamond Group (SDG) to his brother Daniel.<ref>[http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2014/03/30/swiss-newspaper-reports-beny-steinmetz-sells-interest-in-diamond-business/ Swiss Newspaper Reports Beny Steinmetz Sells Interest In Diamond Business], ''[[Jewish Business News]]'', 30 March 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/apr/09/guinea-strips-beny-steinmetz-bsg-resources-mining-contracts-corruption|title=Guinea to strip Beny Steinmetz company of mining concessions|publisher=The Guardian|date=9 April 2014}}</ref> He is an investor of Gabriel Resources Ltd.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miningweekly.com/article/steinmetz-unit-invests-in-gabriel-resources-2009-11-12|title=Steinmetz unit invests in Gabriel Resources|publisher=Mining Weekly|date=12 November 2009}}</ref>
[[Koidu Holdings]], which formerly operated as a joint venture, has been wholly owned by the BSGR company since 2007.<ref name="koiduholdings">[http://www.koiduholdings.com/company-history.php Koidu Holdings Company History] Retrieved 2012-12-15</ref><ref name="baxter">Joan Baxter, ''Dust from our eyes: an unblinkered look at Africa'', Wolsak and Wynn Publishers Ltd., 2008, p. 226 [https://books.google.com/books?id=I_kMAQAAMAAJ&q=%22beny+steinmetz%22&dq=%22beny+steinmetz%22&hl=en&ei=UtEQTrLjNdSftwfalYn3DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAg]</ref>
In 1997, he founded STI Ventures NV, a [[venture capital]] firm that invests in [[start-up companies]] in Israel.<ref name="stiventuresnv">[http://investing.businessweek.com/businessweek/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=91278 STI Ventures NV BusinessWeek]</ref> In 1999, he was the owner of [[Tucows]].<ref name="isla">''ISLA'', Volume 54, Issue 12, [[Oakland, California]]: Information Services on Latin America, 1999, pg. 7379 [https://books.google.com/books?id=eTAcAQAAIAAJ&q=%22beny+steinmetz%22&dq=%22beny+steinmetz%22&hl=en&ei=cNgQTqPrI4KbtwfdwcXjDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q6AEwADgK]</ref> BSGR and another investment firm, IMR, also control Cunico. A now-defunct company, of which he was a founder and shareholder, [[Nikanor plc]], listed in London, was acquired by [[Katanga Mining]] in 2008.<ref name="KatangaHist" /> With his company called Scorpio, he owns real estate in [[Kazakhstan]], Russia, and Eastern Europe.<ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="haaretz"/>
The March 2011 issue of ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine estimated his personal wealth at US$6 billion.<ref name="forbes">[https://www.forbes.com/profile/beny-steinmetz ''Forbes Rich List'': The World's Billionaires 2011 - Beny Steinmetz], forbes.com; accessed 21 February 2018.</ref>
As of March 2011, he was the second richest person in Israel, before [[Sammy Ofer]] died in June 2011.<ref name="jerusalempost">[http://www.jpost.com/Business/BusinessNews/Article.aspx?id=211540 "Sammy Ofer tops Israelis in 'Forbes' billionaires list"], ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', 10 March 2011.</ref> According to Forbes in June 2014, Steinmetz is the sixth richest Israeli in the world with a net worth of $3.5 billion.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/profile/beny-steinmetz Beny Steinmetz profile], ''[[Forbes]]''; retrieved 21 February 2018.</ref>
==Controversy== In December 2008, a three-year exploration permit for [[Simandou]] Blocks 1 & 2, in the [[Republic of Guinea]], was awarded to BSGR Guinea, after the government of Guits to mine the northern half of Simandou, days before he died, to Steinmetz for $160 million. Steinmetz then soon sold a 51% share on to [[Vale (mining company)|Vale]] for $2.5 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21603507-guineas-government-may-last-be-dealing-sensibly-its-mineral-riches-let|title=Guinea and its iron ore: Let the people benefit, for once|magazine=The Economist|date=7 June 2014}}</ref>
The [[U.S. Justice Department]] and the [[FBI]] investigated BSGR's acquisition of the rights to extract half of the iron ore deposits at [[Simandou|Simandou, Guinea]], due to concerns about corruption and bribery.<ref name="nyer2013"/><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/16/fbi-arrest-bribery-10bn-mountain FBI arrest agent over bribery cover up claim in battle over $10bn mountain], ''The Guardian'', 16 April 2013.</ref><ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/the-corruption-deal-of-the-century-how-guinea-lost-billions-of-pounds-in-simandou-mining-licensing-8662534.html "The corruption deal of the century: How Guinea lost billions of pounds in Simandou mining licensing], ''The Independent'', 17 June 2013.</ref><ref>{{YouTube|HOfNE2gZH1o}}</ref> BSGR denied these allegations and in an interview to the ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'', Steinmetz said: “We are the victims. We have done only good things for Guinea, and what we’re getting is spit in the face."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/07/08/buried-secrets|title=Buried Secrets|magazine=The New Yorker|access-date=12 December 2016}}</ref>
In April 2014 the Guinean government accused BSGR of obtaining the Simandou mining rights by paying bribes to the wife of then-president [[Lansana Conté]] in 2008, and that the rights would be stripped from BSGR and its partner [[Vale (mining company)|Vale S.A.]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Guinea to strip Beny Steinmetz company of mining concessions|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/apr/09/guinea-strips-beny-steinmetz-bsg-resources-mining-contracts-corruption|accessdate=1 May 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=9 April 2014|author=Ian Cobain|author2=Juliette Garside|author3=Anne Penketh}}</ref>
In September 2014 BSGR started an [[international arbitration]] proceeding against the Republic of Guinea in the [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes]], challenging the government's decision to revoke its mining rights.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/guinea-mining-simandou-idUSL5N0RB45320140910|title=BSGR pushes ahead with arbitration against Guinea over Simandou mining rights|date=10 September 2014|agency=Reuters}}</ref>
[[Rio Tinto Group|Rio Tinto]] then filed suit against Steinmetz, BSGR and Vale alleging that they had devised a [[RICO]] scheme to steal "valuable mining rights" held by Rio Tinto.<ref name="GUA1may">{{cite news|last=Cobain|first=Ian|title=Rio Tinto sues Israeli billionaire Beny Steinmetz|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/may/01/rio-tinto-sues-beny-steinmetz|accessdate=2 May 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=1 May 2014}}</ref>
Steinmetz subsequently hired former FBI director [[Louis Freeh]], defense attorney [[Alan Dershowitz]], and law firm [[Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom]], as part of his defense team.<ref>{{cite news|last=Silverstein|first=Ken|authorlink=Ken Silverstein|url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2015/01/02/louis-freehs-latest-investigation-billionaire-businessman-accused-bribing-african-government|title=Louis Freeh's Latest Investigation: Billionaire Businessman Accused of Bribing African Government|work=[[The Intercept]]|date=2 January 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102234158/https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2015/01/02/louis-freehs-latest-investigation-billionaire-businessman-accused-bribing-african-government|archivedate=2 January 2015}}</ref>
In November 2015, Rio Tinto's RICO lawsuit against BSGR was dismissed, with U.S. District Judge [[Richard Berman]] ruling that Rio exceeded the [[statute of limitations]] when filing their claim against BSGR in 2014 and that the company failed to identify a pattern of racketeering activity by the defendants.<ref>{{Cite news|authors=Erik Larson & Bob Van Voris|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-20/steinmetz-bsg-resources-win-ruling-dismissing-rio-tinto-suit|title=Steinmetz, BSG Resources Win Dismissal of Rio Tinto Lawsuit|publisher=Bloomberg News|date=20 November 2015}}</ref>
In mid-November 2016, Alan Davies, head of the Rio Tinto department responsible for Simandou, was suspended due to an investigation into the lawfulness of Rio Tinto's payment to Francois de Combert, former managing partner at Lazard and personal adviser to the president of Guinea.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-11-11/billionaire-steinmetz-says-rio-probe-proves-guinea-mine-plot|title=Billionaire Says Rio Probe Proves Elaborate Plot to Strip Prized Guinea Mine Rights|date=11 November 2016|publisher=Bloomberg News|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
On 1 December 2016, ''[[France 24]]'' aired recordings from 2012 that it claimed were conversations between Francois de Combret and unnamed people involved in negotiations over the future of Simandou.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20161201-exclusive-audio-recordings-guinea-president-conde-simandou-mine-bribery-rio-tinto|title=Audio recordings drag Guinea president into mine bribery scandal|date=1 December 2016|newspaper=France 24|access-date=12 December 2016}}</ref>
Australian media referred to the controversy as ''Guineagate''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.afr.com/business/mining/iron-ore/recordings-suggest-rio-tinto-consultant-hand-in-hand-with-guinea-20161202-gt2lbw|title=French claims Rio's consultant working 'hand in hand' with officials in Guinea|date=2 December 2016|newspaper=Financial Review||access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref>
In December 2016, Steinmetz was arrested on suspicion of money laundering and bribery charges following an investigation carried out by Israeli, American, Swiss, and Guinean authorities in coordination with the [[OECD]].<ref name="Billionaire">{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/billionaire-vs-billionaire-israels-steinmetz-sues-soros|title=Billionaire vs. billionaire: Israel's Steinmetz sues Soros|work=The Times of Israel|access-date=18 April 2017}}</ref>
He was placed under [[house arrest]] on 19 December 2016, due to accusations that he paid tens of millions of dollars to senior public officials in Guinea to advance his businesses, specifically in connection with BSGR's purchase of Simandou.<ref name="ReutersSuit">{{cite news|title=BSGR sues billionaire George Soros over loss of Guinea iron project|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bsgr-lawsuit-idUSKBN17G1LL|agency=Reuters}}</ref> Steinmetz was released without charge the following month.<ref name="ReutersSuit"/><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-corruption-steinmetz-idUSKBN14O1QT Billionaire Beny Steinmetz released from Israel house arrest], Reuters.com, 4 January 2017.</ref>
In April 2017, BSGR filed a suit against American billionaire [[George Soros]] in U.S. federal court in New York, claiming he had engaged in a lengthy effort to defame the company and sabotage its business in Simandou and around the world.<ref name="ReutersSuit"/><ref name="Billionaire"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-14/george-soros-sued-by-fellow-billionaire-in-10-billion-mine-row|title=Soros Sued by Fellow Billionaire in $10 Billion Mine Brawl|date=14 April 2017|publisher=Bloomberg News|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref> A Soros spokesman called the allegations "frivolous and entirely false" and described the lawsuit as "a desperate [[PR stunt]] meant to deflect attention from BSGR's mounting legal problems across multiple jurisdictions."<ref>Tara Cunningham, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2017/04/15/miner-bsg-resources-sues-billionaire-george-soros-loss-guinea "Miner BSG Resources sues billionaire George Soros over loss of Guinea iron project"], ''Telegraph'', 15 April 2017.</ref>
On 10 March 2016, Steimetz was indicted [[Trial in absentia|''in absentia'']] by Romanian [[National Anticorruption Directorate]], on charges of the unlawful recovery of [[Paul-Philippe Hohenzollern]]'s inheritance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antena3.ro/actualitate/dna-cere-arestarea-strategului-lui-basescu-345480.html|title=Bombă aruncată de DNA: Se cere arestarea a patru afaceriști extrem de influenţi|publisher=antena3|date=10 March 2016|language=ro}}</ref> The court in Romania dismissed the request for a warrant for his arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-romanian-court-refuses-arrest-warrant-for-beny-steinmetz-1001126076|title=Romanian court refuses Steinmetz arrest warrant|website=Globes|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref>
On 14 August 2017, Steinmetz was arrested as part of a joint investigation by Israeli and Swiss anti-corruption officials over allegations of fraud, breach of trust, bribery, obstruction of justice and false registration of corporate documents" with the apparent purpose of money laundering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Israeli-billionaire-arrested-in-international-money-laundering-probe-502413|title=Israeli billionaire arrested in int'l money laundering probe|last1=Eisenbud |first1=Daniel|last2=Shaham|first2=Udi|date=14 August 2017|website=jpost.com|publisher=Jerusalem Post|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
== Philanthropy == In 2007, Steinmetz and his wife Agnes founded the Agnes and Beny Steinmetz Foundation in order to unify their multiple volunteer activities under the auspices of one philanthropic organization. The Foundation is primarily engaged in financing projects in the fields of education, healthcare, and culture for young children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?fbdid=1001158166|title=מי הגיע לאירוע ההוקרה של קרן אניאס ובני שטיינמץ? - גלובס|website=Globes|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref>
The Agnes and Beny Steinmetz Foundation also supports programs that work with at-risk youth, runs after-school facilities for children from disadvantaged families,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steinmetz-foundation.com/?module=category&item_id=20|title=The Agnes & Beny Steinmetz Foundation|website=www.steinmetz-foundation.com|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref> and offers scholarships to students from difficult socio-economic backgrounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.netanya.ac.il/Interested/Scholarships/Pages/Scholarships7.aspx|title=netanya.ac.il/Interested/Scholarships/Pages/Scholarships7.aspx|website=www.netanya.ac.il|language=he-il|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref>
The Foundation also donates to several organizations and institutions, including the Tel Aviv Museum, the Association for the Wellbeing of Israel's Soldiers (mainly supporting the soldiers of the Tzabar Battalion Of the Givati Brigade),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ametz.awis.org.il/1147-2|title=חוגגים עשור לקרן אניאס ובני שטיינמץ {{!}} המגזין של פרויקט אמץ לוחם|website=ametz.awis.org.il|language=he-IL|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref> the Israel Cancer Association, and various hospitals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steinmetzfoundationnews.com/he/home|title=קרן אניאס ובני שטיינמץ {{!}} עמוד הבית|website=www.steinmetzfoundationnews.com|language=he-il|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref>
At the end of 2016, the Foundation held a festive event to celebrate a decade of giving. Attendants included representatives of the many organizations the Foundation had supported over the years by contributing a cumulative amount of tens of millions of shekels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steinmetzfoundationnews.com/ten-years-celebration|title=אירוע חגיגת עשור לקרן אניאס ובני שטינמץ|website=steinmetzfoundationnews.com|access-date=21 February 2018|language=he-il}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|refs=<ref name=KatangaHist>{{cite web|url=http://www.katangamining.com/kat/about_us/history|title=History|publisher=Katanga Mining|accessdate=21 February 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110080329/http://www.katangamining.com/kat/about_us/history|archivedate=10 November 2011}}</ref>}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2015}}
{{Infobox Magazine | image_file =File:Bplusp masthead3b.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = | company = Books and Publishing Pty Ltd | circulation = 2900 (January 2018) | frequency = Quarterly | language = [[Australian English]] | category = [[Books]], [[news]], [[bookselling]], [[publishing]], [[book reviews]], and [[libraries]] | editor = Andrew Wrathall | founded = 1921 | country = Australia | based = Melbourne | website = [http://www.booksandpublishing.com.au/ www.booksandpublishing.com.au] | issn = 2201-5892 }} '''''Books+Publishing''''' magazine (formerly '''''Bookseller+Publisher''''' and '''''Australian Bookseller & Publisher''''') is the quarterly journal of the Australian [[book industry]]<ref name=about>{{cite news|title=About Books+Publishing|url=http://www.booksandpublishing.com.au/about/|accessdate=29 October 2016|work=Books+Publishing}}</ref> and is one of Australia's oldest surviving magazines. The magazine contains book news, author interviews, category round-ups and features on forthcoming books, and pre-publication reviews of Australian and New Zealand books.
==History== ''Books+Publishing'' magazine was founded in 1921<ref name=about/><ref name=bow>{{cite web|title=Books+Publishing Magazine|url=http://www.bowker.com/products/BooksPublishing.html|work=Bowker|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> by Daniel Wrixon Thorpe as the '''''Australian Stationery and Fancy Goods Journal''''', at a time when there were few Australian retailers solely focused on the sale of books. The magazine has been continuously [[published]] ever since, changing its name to ''Ideas'' in the 1937. The name then change to ''Australian Bookseller & Publisher'' in 1971 when the D W Thorpe company was taken over by Thorpe's daughter, [[Joyce Nicholson]].<ref name=numbering>{{cite web|title=Books+Publishing magazine numbering|url=https://www.booksandpublishing.com.au/magazine-numbering/|accessdate=18 May 2018|website=Books+Publishing|publisher=Books+Publishing}}</ref>
In 1971, the company began publishing the ''Weekly Book Newsletter''—an offshoot of the magazine—containing weekly book-industry news and became colloquially known as the ''Blue News'', because of the blue paper it was printed on.<ref>Nicholson, Joyce & Thorpe, Daniel Wrixon (2000). [https://books.google.com/books?id=PPq_3dPi_XIC ''A Life of Books: The Story of D.W. Thorpe Pty. Ltd., 1921-1987''], Courtyard Press, Melbourne. {{ISBN|0-646-39611-0}}.</ref><ref>Munro, Craig & Sheahan-Bright, Robyn (2006). [https://books.google.com/books?id=VRM7i0OhEIkC ''Paper Empires: A History of the Book in Australia 1946-2005''], University of Queensland Press, Brisbane. {{ISBN|0-7022-3573-3}}.</ref>
The D W Thorpe company was sold to Reed Reference Publishing in 1992, then sold to [[R.R. Bowker]] in 2001, and the company became Thorpe-Bowker in 2003.<ref name=bow/> (R.R. Bowker is currently owned by [[ProQuest]].)
The word 'Australian' was dropped from the magazine's title at the start of 2006 to become ''Bookseller+Publisher'', partly in acknowledgement of Australia's growing role as a publishing and [[bookselling]] hub for the entire Asia-Pacific region. <ref>{{cite web|title=Database of Bookseller+Publisher magazine (2006 to 2012)|url=https://search.informit.org/browseJournalTitle;res=IELAPA;issn=1833-5403|accessdate=18 May 2018|website=Informit |publisher=Informit}}</ref> In 2006 the ''Weekly Book Newsletter'', became an online newsletter that is emailed to subscribers and available on the website.
The publication was renamed to ''Books+Publishing'' in 2012,<ref>{{cite web|title=Database of Books+Publishing (2013 to 2018)|url=https://search.informit.org/browseJournalTitle;res=IELLCC;issn=2201-5892|accessdate=18 May 2018|website=Informit |publisher=Informit}}</ref> and the newsletter ''Library News'' that Thorpe-Bowker had acquired in 2007 was folded into the renamed publication. Two offshoot newsletters carrying book reviews, the ''Reviews Newsletter'' and the ''Junior Newsletter'', began in 2012, and one year later the first ''Daily Newsletter'' was sent out to subscribers containing news about the book industry on a daily basis, which is republished in the ''Weekly Book Newsletter''. The ''Think Australian Newsletter'' and ''Think Australian Junior Newsletter'' were established in 2017, containing news about the sale of rights of Australian titles for an international audience.
On 1 July 2018, Thorpe-Bowker sold the entire ''Books+Publishing'' publication, including the magazine, newsletters and website, to Thorpe-Bowker General Manager Gary Pengelly, under the company Books and Publishing Pty Ltd.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pengelly buys ‘Books+Publishing’. Tang steps down as EIC |url=https://www.booksandpublishing.com.au/articles/2018/07/02/110579/pengelly-buys-bookspublishing-tang-steps-down-as-eic/|accessdate=21 September 2018|website=Books+Publishing |publisher=Books+Publishing}}</ref>
<ref name=numbering/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.booksandpublishing.com.au ''Books+Publishing'' website]

revision.text:
{{Globalize/US|date=January 2017}}
'''Business licenses''' are permits issued by [[government agency|government agencies]] that allow individuals or companies to conduct business within the government's geographical [[jurisdiction]]. It is the authorization to start a business issued by the local government.<ref>{{cite book | last = O'Sullivan | first = Arthur | authorlink = Arthur O'Sullivan (economist) | first2 = Steven M. | last2 = Sheffrin | authorlink2 = Steven M. Sheffrin | title = Economics: Principles in Action | publisher = Pearson Prentice Hall | date = 2003 | location = Upper Saddle River, New Jersey | page = 186 | isbn = 0-13-063085-3}}</ref> A single jurisdiction often requires multiple licenses that are issued by multiple government departments and agencies. Business licenses vary between countries, states, and local municipalities. There are often many licenses, registrations and certifications required to conduct a business in a single location.
Typically, a company's business activity and physical location (address) determines which licenses are required to operate lawfully. Other determining factors may include the number of employees and the [[business#Basic forms of ownership|form of business ownership]], such as sole proprietor or corporation. Government agencies can fine or close a business operating without the required business licenses.
==Licensing and business registration requirements== ===United States=== In the United States, the [[Small Business Administration]] has a list of links to State websites for State licensing requirements.<ref>[http://www.sba.gov/hotlist/license.html SBA: Where to Obtain Business Licenses] Accessed 1 April 2007.</ref> Each State has its own business registration and licensing requirements. [[Business.usa.gov]] is an official business link to the U.S. Government. Business.gov, managed by the U.S. Small Business Administration.
====Example: Washington, D.C.==== In [[Washington, D.C.]] ::The '''Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs''' (DCRA) is the District of Columbia's regulatory agency. DCRA ensures the health, safety, and economic welfare of District residents through licensing, inspection, compliance, and enforcement programs. In addition, '''Department of Health''' (DOH) issues certain professional licenses, '''[[District of Columbia Department of Transportation|District Department of Transportation]]''' (DDOT) regulates public space, and '''Office of Zoning''' (DCOZ) controls land use.<ref>[http://brc.dc.gov/licenses/licenses.asp Washington, D.C. Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs - Licenses and Permits] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070404044839/http://brc.dc.gov/licenses/licenses.asp |date=April 4, 2007 }} Accessed 1 April 2007.</ref> Most individuals and companies doing business in the District of Columbia must obtain a Basic Business License from the Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs.<ref>[http://mblr.dc.gov/ Washington, D.C. Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs - Basic Business License Information] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401143835/http://mblr.dc.gov/ |date=April 1, 2007 }}</ref> Separately, organizations (including non-profits and cooperatives, but not including sole-proprietorships and general partnerships) must register their business. Many types of businesses require additional certification or permits beyond the Basic Business License and registration. D.C. requires a "Clean Hands Self-Certification" from most applicants, which is an affidavit stating that the applicant does not owe more than $100 to the District. Tour Guides must submit a Physician's Certificate. Fees for businesses licenses vary. The fee for a Special Event license such as a marathon is $209. The license for a movie theater costs $1,079 per year, for a grocery store $289 per year, for a beauty shop $78 per year. (2003 schedule of fees, current as of March 2007) A Project Management Firm does not require a Basic Business License, nor does a Handyman. Residential House Painters must submit a Home Improvement Contract signed by the homeowner.
Physicians and other health care professionals require licenses from the Professional Licensing Administration in the Department of Health.<ref>[http://hpla.doh.dc.gov/hpla/cwp/view,a,1195,q,488169,hplaNav, |30661|,.asp Washington, D.C. Health Professional Licensing Administration: Professional Licensing Boards]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
====Example: Pennsylvania==== Pennsylvania allows online registration of small business start-ups, but does not provide licensing guidance. ::The Pennsylvania Open for Business Online Business Registration Interview (OBRI) is a step-by-step wizard that guides users through the process of registering an enterprise with the Departments of Labor & Industry, Revenue, and State. ::The OBRI is a business registration tool and is not intended to be a replacement for professional consultation with qualified practitioners. The laws and regulations governing business start-up, practice, and expansion are varied and compliance with such standards depends upon the particular circumstances of a business. If legal advice or other expert assistance is required, the services of a competent professional should be sought.<ref>[http://sohanroy.com Pennsylvania Online Business Registration Interview] Accessed 1 April 2007.</ref> Certain actions are required by all businesses in Pennsylvania in order for them to continue in business in [[Pennsylvania]].<ref>[http://www.paopen4businessbriefcase.state.pa.us/tax/default.asp?LN=380&LG=41 Pennsylvania - Forms for all Businesses] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513050047/http://www.paopen4businessbriefcase.state.pa.us/tax/default.asp?LN=380&LG=41 |date=May 13, 2007 }} Accessed 1 April 2007.</ref> This includes New Hire Reporting (including reporting oneself as a new hire when starting a business).
==See also== * [[BizPaL]], Canadian service for SME permits and licenses * [[List of company registers]] * [[Barriers to entry]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [[wikihow:Obtain-a-Business-License|How to Obtain a Business License]] - a wikiHow article on getting a business license.
[[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Business law]]

{{Infobox company |name = '''COSMED''' |type = [[Private company|Private]] |foundation = 1980 |location = [[Rome]] [[Italy]] |area_served = [[World]]wide |logo = Cosmed portrait logo 2014.png |num_employees = 120 (2013) |industry = [[Medical Technology]] |products = [[Medical devices]]
Clinical services |homepage = [http://www.cosmed.com/ cosmed.com] }} '''COSMED''' is a privately held, international, [[medical technology]] corporation specialized in [[Metabolism|Metabolic]] and Cardio Pulmonary [[diagnostic test]]ing equipment aimed for either professional or medical use in different application fields ([[Hospital]], [[Sports Science]], [[Health care]], [[Professional sports]] and [[Wellness (medicine)|Wellness]]). == History == Founded in 1980 and based in Rome, Italy, COSMED started manufacturing portable [[spirometer]]s and [[pulmonary function testing]] equipment. In the nineties the company introduced new systems for [[gas exchange]] measurements and patented the first portable system with telemetric data transmission for the measurement of [[Metabolism|metabolic]] parameters during field testing. "Google Patents - Portable system with telemetric data transmission for the measurement of metabolic parameters" https://www.google.com/patents/US6206837?dq=cosmed&ei=-oWoUtmoFIa47QbRsIGQCw&cl=en During early 2000 COSMED started to expand international business incorporating subsidiaries and registered offices in several countries (USA, China, Germany, UK). In 2011, COSMED USA, Inc. completed the acquisition of US company Life Measurement, Inc. (LMI),"COSMED Announces Acquisition Of Life Measurement, Inc. (LMI)" http://www.i-newswire.com/cosmed-announces-acquisition-of/87124 provider of [[Body Composition|body composition]] assessment equipment based on [[Whole-body air displacement plethysmography|Air Displacement Plethysmography]] technology. == Products == COSMED manufactures a full range of [[spirometer]]s, [[Pulmonary function testing|Pulmonary Function Test]] (PFT), Cardio Pulmonary Exercise Test (CPET) and [[Calorimetry|Indirect Calorimetry]] diagnostic equipment. Since 2011, with the acquisition of Life Measurement Inc. (LMI), COSMED manufactures also [[Body Composition|body composition]] assessment equipment for infants, children and adults. COSMED main brands include: BOD POD, PEA POD, K4b2, Fitmate, Quark, Pony FX, microQuark, Spiropalm, Omnia == Appearances == COSMED products were selected to outfit the physiology assessment laboratory in the 23rd James Bond film [[Skyfall]]. COSMED products were used on-screen by the [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] medical staff to assess James Bond’s [[Cardiorespiratory fitness|cardio respiratory performance and fitness level]]."James Bond Lifestyle - COSMED Fitness Equipment http://www.jamesbondlifestyle.com/product/cosmed-fitness-equipment == Awards == COSMED product Spiropalm 6MWT handheld spirometer won the 2013 Product of Outstanding Interest (POINT) Award from the [[European Respiratory Society]] (ERS) during the ERS Congress in Barcelona (Spain).“WINNERS of ERS Product of Outstanding Interest 2013” http://www.ersbuyersguide.org/2012-10-03-09-57-17/awards/award-winners-2013 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212223246/http://www.ersbuyersguide.org/2012-10-03-09-57-17/awards/award-winners-2013# |date=2013-12-12 }} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.cosmed.com COSMED Official Web Site] * [http://www.bodpod.com BOD POD Official Page] {{DEFAULTSORT:COSMED}} [[Category:Medical technology companies of Italy]] [[Category:Privately held companies of Italy]] [[Category:Multinational health care companies]] [[Category:Companies established in 1980]] [[Category:Italian brands]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2015}} '''Chartered Cost Accountant''' ('''CCA''') is a [[cost accounting]] or cost control professional designation offered by the [[American Academy of Financial Management]]. The CCA is a Graduate Post Nominal (GPN) that is only available for accountants with an accredited degree, [[MBA]], [[Certified Public Accountant|CPA]], [[Chartered Accountant]] License, law degree, PhD or specialized executive training.
==See also== * [[Accountant]]
== External Board of Standards Links == *[http://www.financialanalyst.org/ AAPM Amer. Academy of Financial Management]
[[Category:Management accounting]] [[Category:Accounting qualifications]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/Finl0573|Finl0573]] ([[User talk:Finl0573|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
The '''chief compliance officer''' ('''CCO''') of a company is the officer primarily responsible for overseeing and managing [[regulatory compliance]] issues within an organization. The CCO typically reports to the [[Chief executive officer|Chief Executive Office]]<nowiki/>r or [[Chief operating officer|Chief Operations Officer]].
The role has long existed at companies that operate in heavily regulated industries such as [[financial services]] and [[healthcare]]. For other companies, the rash of 2000s [[accounting scandals]], the [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]], and the recommendations of the U.S. Federal Sentencing Guidelines have led to additional CCO appointments.
Scott Cohen, editor and publisher of ''[[Compliance Week]]'', dates the proliferation of CCOs to a 2002 speech by SEC commissioner [[Cynthia Glassman]], in which she called on companies to designate a "corporate responsibility officer."<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/news/speech/spch586.htm SEC Commissioner's Speech: Sarbanes-Oxley and the Idea of "Good" Governance (Cynthia A. Glassman)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The responsibilities of the position often include leading enterprise compliance efforts, designing and implementing internal controls, policies and procedures to assure compliance with applicable local, state and federal laws and regulations and third party guidelines; managing audits and investigations into regulatory and compliance issues; and responding to requests for information from regulatory bodies.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.corporatecompliance.org Society of Corporate Compliance and Ethics (SCCE)] * [http://www.hcca-info.org Health Care Compliance Association (HCCA)] * [http://www.corporatecompliance.org/Resources/View/smid/940/ArticleID/750.aspx Leading Corporate Integrity: Defining the Role of the Chief Ethics and Compliance Officer] * [http://www.corporatecompliance.org/Resources/View/smid/940/ArticleID/675.aspx SCCE Code of Ethics for Compliance and Ethics Professionals]
{{corporate titles}}
[[Category:Corporate governance]] [[Category:Regulatory compliance]] [[Category:Corporate titles|C]]
{{management-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Accounting}} '''Control self-assessment''' is a technique developed in 1987 that is used by a range of organisations including corporations, charities and government departments, to assess the effectiveness of their risk management and control processes.
A "control process" is a check or process performed to reduce or [[risk elimination|eliminate the risk]] of error. Since its introduction the technique has been widely adopted in the United States, European Union and other countries. There are a number of ways a control self-assessment can be implemented but its key feature is that, in contrast to a traditional [[audit]], the tests and checks are made by staff whose normal day-to-day responsibilities are within the business unit being assessed.<ref name=CPAJournal>{{cite web|url=http://www.nysscpa.org/cpajournal/2005/1205/essentials/p38.htm|title=The Use of Control Self-Assessment by Independent Auditors|author1=Gilbert W. Joseph |author2=Terry J. Engle |date=December 2005|accessdate=2012-03-10|publisher=The CPA Journal}}</ref> A self-assessment, by identifying the higher risk processes within the organisation, allows [[internal auditor]]s to plan their work more effectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theiia.org/training/index.cfm?act=seminar.detail&semID=38|title=Control Self-assessment: An Introduction|publisher=[[The Institute of Internal Auditors]]|accessdate=2012-03-10}}</ref> A number of governmental organisations require the use of control self-assessment. In the [[United States]] it is a requirement of the [[FFIEC]] that control self-assessments are performed on IT systems and operational processes on a regular basis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ithandbook.ffiec.gov/it-booklets/operations/risk-assessment-.aspx|title=FFIEC IT Examination Handbook|publisher=FFIEC|accessdate=2012-03-10}}</ref> Benefits claimed for control self-assessment include creating a clear line of accountability for controls, reducing the risk of fraud and the creation of an organisation with a lower risk profile.<ref name=accountingweb/><ref name="John Wiley & Sons Ltd">{{cite book|title=The Internal Auditing Handbook|edition=3rd|author=Spencer Pickett, K.H.|author2=Pickett, Jennifer M.|last-author-amp=yes|page=585|publisher=John Wiley & Sons Ltd.|year=2010}}</ref>
In certain circumstances control self-assessment is not always effective. For example, it can be difficult to implement in a decentralised environment, in organisations where there is high employee turnover, where the organisation goes through frequent change or where the senior management of the organisation does not foster a culture of open communication.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.protiviti.com/en-US/Documents/White-Papers/Industries/Control_Self_Assessment_Whitepaper.pdf|title=Control Self-Assessment:The Future of Store Audits in Retail Stores|publisher=Protivit Incorporated|year=2006|accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref>
==Development and worldwide adoption==
Control self-assessment was developed by Gulf Canada in 1987 when the company's [[Chief audit executive|General Auditor]], Bruce McCuaig was dissatisfied with the standard auditing techniques in use following the impact of the [[Watergate]] affair on the parent company, [[Gulf Oil|Gulf Oil Corporation]]. The decision to fully implement control self-assessment at Gulf Canada was driven by a number of factors. These included the presence of a [[consent decree]] requiring the company to report on its internal controls and the difficulties it was facing in estimating its oil and gas reserves using more traditional audit measures.<ref name=profpractice>{{cite book|url=http://www.iiajapan.com/pdf/data/csa/pp98-2.pdf|title=Professional Practice Pamphlet 98-2 A Perspective on Control Self-Assessment|publisher=[[The Institute of Internal Auditors]]|location=[[Florida]]|year=1998|ISBN=089413406X|accessdate=2012-03-31}}</ref>
Over the next ten years Gulf Canada developed a framework to support the analysis and evaluation of control processes by operational staff. This included anonymous voting to ensure there was no impediment to staff expressing their views. The approach was first published in ''[[Internal Auditor]]'' in December 1990.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Essential Guide to Internal Auditing|edition=Second|author=K.H. Spencer Pickett|page=81|publisher=John Wiley & Sons Limited|year=2011}}</ref> Gulf Canada discontinued this facilitated meeting approach in 1997 although it continued with control self-assessment using different techniques.<ref name=profpractice/>
Following Gulf Canada's introduction of control self-assessment many private sector organisations implemented similar techniques. In the United States several states made reviews based on control self-assessment practices mandatory as did the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation]] and the [[Canadian Deposit Insurance Corporation]].<ref name=profpractice/>
Initially external auditors ignored the benefits of control self-assessment even though it was effective at providing audit evidence around the "soft" areas (such as staff morale) that are critical to the effectiveness of internal control systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/human-resources/workforce-management/1071523-1.html|title=Use of control self-assessment in audits|accessdate=2012-03-12|date=1 August 2001|publisher=The CPA Journal|author=Joseph, Gilbert W}}</ref>
After a number of financial scandals, notably the collapse of [[Robert Maxwell]]'s publishing empire, the United Kingdom government commissioned [[Adrian Cadbury]] to chair an investigation into corporate governance. The committee published its report [[Cadbury Report|''The Financial Aspects of Corporate Governance'']] in 1992. In section 4, Reporting and Controls, Cadbury made a number of recommendations that led to the increased adoption of control self-assessment in the UK. In particular section 4.5 of the Code of Practice contained within the report required that the directors of a company should report on the effectiveness of the company's system of internal control in each [[annual report]].<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.ecgi.org/codes/documents/cadbury.pdf|title=Financial Aspects of Corporate Governance|date=1 December 1992|ISBN=0852589131|accessdate=2012-03-12|page=}}</ref>
In March 2000 the [[European Commission]] approved a white paper on reform that led to a major change in the way the Commission was managed. These changes included recommendations for each department to establish an effective internal control system. To support the implementation of the internal controls the [[Directorate-General for Budget]]'s Central Financial Service developed a control self-assessment process. This first control self-assessment identified several areas for improvement in internal control across the Commission most notably the need to implement a more systematic approach to risk management. The outcome of this first self-assessment was the implementation of the requirement for every [[Directorate General]] to perform a control and risk self-assessment annually.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.4qconference.org/en/previous_quality/2QC/The_Internal_Control_and_Risk_Self-Assessment.doc|title=2nd Quality Conference for Public Administration in the EU: Note for the File|author=Central Financial Service, European Commission|author2-link=European Commission|date=18 March 2002|accessdate=2012-03-12}}</ref>
In 2007 the United States implemented the [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]]. In order to comply with section 404 of the Act the company had to perform a top down risk assessment which necessitated the production of an "internal control report" that affirmed "the responsibility of management for establishing and maintaining an adequate internal control structure and procedures for financial reporting." {{uscsub|15|7262|a}}. This report has to include an evaluation of the effectiveness of the internal controls and procedures that are related to financial reporting. To meet this requirement organisations increasingly began to perform a control self-assessment using a recognised standard methodology. The organisation's external auditors, who are required to sign-off the internal control report, typically became more deeply involved in the control self-assessment process as it facilitated their later review of the internal control report.<ref name=IIEAC>{{cite journal|url=http://www.theiia.org/CSA/index.cfm?iid=537&catid=0&aid=2670|title=Improving Internal and External Audit Coordination|author1=Engel, Terry J. |author2=Joseph, Gilbert W.|agency=[[The Institute of Internal Auditors]]|publisher=CSA Sentinel|volume=11|number=2|year=2007|accessdate=2012-04-02}}</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom]] in 2011 the [[Financial Services Authority]] recognised in its recommendations for the improvement of operational risk management that the assessment of risks through a control self-assessment may be an important means of identifying risks. It also noted that for the assessment to be fully effective it had to be fully integrated into the financial organisation's risk-management process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsa.gov.uk/pubs/guidance/guidance11.pdf|publisher=[[Financial Services Authority]]|date=January 2011|title=Enhancing frameworks in the standardised approach to operational risk – Guidance note|accessdate=2012-03-11}}</ref>
== Performing the control self-assessment == [[File:Transit Board control self-assessment form.jpg|thumb|right|Section 1 of the control self-assessment form used by the [[Federal Transit Administration]]]] The first step in control self-assessment is to document the organisation's control processes with the aim of identifying suitable ways of measuring or testing each control. The actual testing of the controls is performed by staff whose day-to-day role is within the area of the organisation that is being examined as they have the greatest knowledge of how the processes operate.<ref name=CPAJournal/><ref name=accountingweb>{{cite web|url=http://www.accountingweb.com/item/104210|title=Control self-assessment:Everybody pitching in with internal controls|author=McNally, J.Stephen|publisher=accountingweb|date=12 November 2007}}</ref> The two common techniques for performing the evaluations are:
* Workshops, that may be but do not have to be independently facilitated, involving some or all staff from the business unit being tested; * Surveys or questionnaires completed independently by the staff.
Both approaches are the opposite of formal audits where the [[auditor]]s, not the business unit staff, will perform the assessment.<ref name=CPAJournal/>
On completion of the assessment each control may be rated based on the responses received to determine the probability of its failure and the impact if a failure occurred. These ratings can be mapped to produce a [[heatmap]] showing potential areas of vulnerability. {{clear}}
==Methodologies== [[File:Risk and Control Impact Assessment.JPG|thumb|A heatmap produced from the information captured in a control self-assessment. The cluster of issues in the red and amber sections of the heatmap indicate that this is a high risk area and probably in need of new or changed control processes.]] Six basic methodologies for control self-assessment have been defined:<ref name=ISACA>{{cite journal|url=http://www.isaca.org/Journal/Past-Issues/2004/Volume-1/Pages/Control-Self-assessment-for-Information-and-Related-Technology.aspx|title=Control Self-assessment for Information and Related Technology|volume=1|year=2004|author=Sunil Bakshi|journal=Journal of the Information Systems Audit and Control Association|page=4}}</ref>
*Internal Control Questionnaire (ICQ) self-audit *Customised questionnaires *Control guides *Interview techniques *Control model workshops *Interactive workshops
The [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] control self-assessment methodology is based on customised questionnaires. It is an [[Information technology|IT]] focused methodology suitable for assessing system based controls. It provides a cost-effective technique to determine the status of information security controls, identify any weaknesses and, where necessary, define an improvement plan.<ref name=NIST>{{cite web|url=http://www.itl.nist.gov/lab/bulletns/bltnsep01.htm|title=Security Self-assessment Guide for Information Technology Systems|author=Marianne Swanson|publisher=[[National Institute of Standards and Technology]]|accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> The methodology uses a questionnaire that contains specific control objectives and techniques against a system or group of systems can be tested and measured. The methodology was designed for United States federal agencies but can also be valuable for private sector organisations.<ref name=NIST/>
The [[COBIT]] methodology can be used for control self-assessment; like the NIST methodology it was designed for IT focused assessments. COBIT's Process Description component provides a reference model of an organisation's processes and their ownership. Its Control Objectives component provides a set of requirements considered necessary for effective control of each IT process with the organisation. Assessment and evaluation of these components using the Management Guidelines component provides an assessment mechanism that generates a maturity model indicating if the organisation is meeting its control objectives.<ref name=ISACA/>
The [[Institute of Internal Auditors]] based its control self-assessment methodology on the [[Total Quality Management]] approaches of the 1990s as well as the [[Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission|COSO's]] framework. The methodology became part of the ''International Standards for Professional Practice of Internal Auditing'' and was adopted by a large number of major organisations.<ref>{{cite book|title=Brink's Modern Internal Auditing: A Common Body of Knowledge|author=Robert Moeller|publisher=John Wiley & Sons Inc., Canada|year=2009}}</ref>
A number of other methodologies to standardise the control self-assessment have been published.<ref>{{cite book|author= Álvarez, Gene|title=Operational Risk: Practical Approaches to Implementation|year=2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.risk.net/operational-risk-and-regulation/feature/1900537/comprehensive-risk-control-self-assessment-methodology|title=A comprehensive risk and control self-assessment methodology|author1=Gene Álvarez |author2=Phil Gledhill |date=24 November 2010|publisher=Risk.net|accessdate=2012-03-10}}</ref> The Institute of Internal Auditors offers a certification in control self-assessment practice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theiia.org/certification/specialty-certifications/ccsa/|publisher=[[Institute of Internal Auditors]]|title=Certification in Control Self Assessment (CCSA)|accessdate=2012-10-03}}</ref>
==Software tools==
A number of software packages are available to support the control self-assessment process. These are typically modified versions of software developed originally for internal use by audit and accountancy firms such as [[Deloitte]] or by niche vendors specialising in business or financial management tools.
==Benefits== Control self-assessment creates a clear line of accountability for controls, reduces the risk of [[fraud]] (by examining data that may flag unusual patterns of transactions) and results in an organisation with a lower risk profile.<ref name=accountingweb/><ref name="John Wiley & Sons Ltd"/>
A number of other soft benefits have been claimed for organisations performing control self-assessment. These include a better understanding of business operations (by both management and operational staff); stronger awareness of risk practices; a reinforced [[corporate governance]] regime and internal audit efficiency improvements.<ref name=accountingweb/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwc.com/th/en/performance-improvement/control-self-assessment.jhtml|accessdate=2012-03-10|publisher=[[PriceWaterhouseCoopers]]|title=Control Self Assessment}}</ref>
==Criticism==
Some researchers have criticised control self-assessment as a flawed approach as the way risk is defined and measured is unsophisticated. In particular, control self-assessment may understate risk by not identifying extreme downside risk. An extreme downside risk is a highly improbable event that would have catastrophic consequences if it occurred. These risks should have a high overall risk score (generally calculated as a product of the probability of a risk occurring and the impact if it does occur on a scale of 1 to 5). Individuals performing the control self-assessment are consequently unable to significantly differentiate between risks leading to extreme low probability risks either being excluded from the analysis or grouped together with other more probable (but still unlikely) risks that have a less severe impact.<ref name=Dragonfly>{{cite web|url=http://dragonflyone.com/docs/Dragonfly_Risk_Insights_CSA_A4_s.pdf|title=Companies Using Control Self Assessment Don't Really Know their Risk|author1=Lee, Judy |author2=Wee, Lieng-Seng|publisher=Dragonfly|accessdate=2012-03-14|date=28 September 2005}}</ref>
The continual focus on risk elimination that a control self-assessment can lead to has also been criticised. The process of continual evaluation of risks and making plans to mitigate and eliminate them may lead to an unbalanced corporate culture where risks are eliminated ignoring the risk-return ratio of different business choices.<ref name=Dragonfly/>
==See also==
*[[Internal audit]] *[[Internal control]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120104011450/http://www.fta.dot.gov/documents/FTA_Internal_Control_Self-Assessment_Tool.pdf Control self-assessment tool] used by the [[Federal Transit Administration]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Control self-assessment}} [[Category:Auditing]] [[Category:Risk management]] [[Category:Corporate governance]] [[Category:Internal audit]]

'''Dahlan Iskan''' ( born August 17, 1951 in [[Magetan]]) is the former [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Indonesia]]n newspaper publisher, [[Jawa Pos|Jawa Pos Group]]. He was the CEO of Indonesia's State Electricity Company, ([[Perusahaan Listrik Negara|PLN]]) from December 23, 2009 to October, 2011.<ref>{{cite web | last = Suharmoko | first = Aditya | authorlink = |author2=Alfian | title = Dahlan Iskan named to lead state power utility PLN | work = | publisher = The Jakarta Post | date = 2009-12-23 | url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/12/23/dahlan-iskan-named-lead-state-power-utility-pln.html | doi = | accessdate = 2011-07-26 }} </ref> He was Indonesia's minister for [[State-owned enterprise]]s in the period October 2011 to October 2014.
[[File:Dahlan Iskan.jpg|right|thumb|Dahlan Iskan in 2013]]
Dahlan is known for his unorthodox, often personalised, approach to solving internal bureaucratic problems and inefficiencies within stated-owned enterprises (SOEs). Over time, he came to have been seen as a somewhat controversial figure. His style as a minister sometimes attracted criticism from members of the [[People's Representative Council|Indonesian parliament]] (MPs).<ref>Amahl S, Azwar, '[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/10/23/lawmakers-target-dahlan-and-his-antics.html Politics: Lawmakers target Dahlan and his antics'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 23 October 2012.</ref> He responded vigorously to criticisms from parliamentarians by threatening to expose details of payments allegedly made by SOEs in order to be able to meet MPs in parliamentary commission hearings. He also supported the Indonesian development of an environmentally friendly car, one of which he often drove himself. However, in a much-publicised incident, he crashed one of the electric cars.<ref>Kusumasari Ayuningtyas and Wahyoe Boediwardhana, '[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/01/05/dahlan-rams-local-sports-car-mountain-slope.html Dahlan rams local sports car into mountain slope'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 5 January 2013.</ref>
Dahlan Iskan is also the author of ''No such thing as Can't'', the biography of Karmaka Surjaudaja, the founder of bank OCBC NISP in Indonesia which has close links with OCBC ([[Overseas-Chinese Banking Corporation]]).<ref>Donny Syofan, '[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/11/04/dahlan-vs-house-lawmakers-replicates-david-vs-goliath-duel.html Dahlan vs House lawmakers replicates David vs Goliath duel?'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 4 November 2012.</ref>
After completing his term as minister for State Owned Enterprises, he is now traveling to some countries to harvest ideas on the area of his interest such as sustainable energy while reporting his observation and analysis in JPNN.
== References == {{Reflist|colwidth=40em}}
== External links == * {{id}} [http://www.jpnn.com/index.php?mib=artikelindeks&ky=3 Iskan's writings published on JPNN]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Iskan, Dahlan}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Indonesian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
According to [[Ralph Kimball]],{{Cite book |first1=Ralph |last1=Kimball |first2=Margy |last2=Ross |title=The Data Warehouse Toolkit: The Complete Guide to Dimensional Modeling (Second Edition) |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |location=Indianapolis, IN |year=2002 |pages=50, 398 |isbn=978-0-471-20024-6 }} in a [[data warehouse]], a '''degenerate dimension''' is a dimension key in the [[fact table]] that does not have its own [[dimension table]], because all the interesting attributes have been placed in analytic dimensions. The term "degenerate dimension" was originated by [[Ralph Kimball]]. As Bob Becker says:{{cquote|Degenerate dimensions commonly occur when the fact table's grain is a single transaction (or transaction line). Transaction control header numbers assigned by the operational business process are typically degenerate dimensions, such as order, ticket, credit card transaction, or check numbers. These degenerate dimensions are natural keys of the "parents" of the line items.
Even though there is no corresponding dimension table of attributes, degenerate dimensions can be quite useful for grouping together related fact tables rows. For example, retail point-of-sale transaction numbers tie all the individual items purchased together into a single market basket. In health care, degenerate dimensions can group the claims items related to a single hospital stay or episode of care.{{cite web|last=Becker|first=Bob|title=Design Tip #46: Another Look At Degenerate Dimensions|date=3 June 2003|url=http://www.kimballgroup.com/2003/06/03/design-tip-46-another-look-at-degenerate-dimensions/|work=Fact Table Core Concepts|publisher=Kimball Group|accessdate=25 January 2013}}}} ==Other uses of the term== Although most writers and practitioners use the term '''degenerate dimension''' correctly, it is very easy to find misleading definitions in online and printed sources. For example, the Oracle FAQ defines a degenerate dimension as a "data dimension that is stored in the fact table rather than a separate dimension table. This eliminates the need to join to a dimension table. You can use the data in the degenerate dimension to limit or 'slice and dice' your fact table measures."{{cite web|title=Degenerate dimension|url=http://orafaq.com/wiki/Degenerate_dimension|work=Oracle FAQ's|accessdate=31 July 2011}} This common interpretation implies that it is good dimensional modeling practice to place dimension attributes in the fact table, as long as you call them a degenerate dimension. This is not the case; the concept of '''degenerate dimension''' was developed by Kimball to support a specific, well-defined exception to the otherwise ironclad rule that dimension attributes are always pulled out into dimension tables. ==See also== * [[data warehouse]] * [[dimension table]] * [[fact table]] * [[measure (data warehouse)]] ==External reference== {{cite web|last=Becker|first=Bob|title=Design Tip #46: Another Look At Degenerate Dimensions|url=http://www.kimballgroup.com/2003/06/03/design-tip-46-another-look-at-degenerate-dimensions/|work=Fact Table Core Concepts|publisher=Kimball Group|accessdate=25 January 2013|date=3 June 2003}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * [[Ralph Kimball|Kimball, Ralph]] et al. (1998); ''The Data Warehouse Lifecycle Toolkit'', p17. Pub. Wiley. {{ISBN|0-471-25547-5}}. * [[Ralph Kimball|Kimball, Ralph]] (1996); ''The Data Warehouse Toolkit'', p. 100. Pub. Wiley. {{ISBN|0-471-15337-0}}. {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Data warehouse}} [[Category:Data warehousing]] [[Category:Metadata]]

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Reduction of the quantity of natural resources" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Reduction of the quantity of natural resources}} {{Other uses|Depletion (disambiguation)}}
'''Depletion''' is an [[accounting]] and [[tax]] concept used most often in [[mining]], [[timber]], [[petroleum]], or other similar industries. The depletion deduction allows an owner or operator to account for the reduction of a product's reserves. Depletion is similar to [[depreciation]] in that it is a cost recovery system for accounting and tax reporting.
Depletion, for both accounting purposes and [[Internal Revenue Service|United States tax purposes]], is a method of recording the gradual expense or use of [[natural resource]]s over time. Depletion is the using up of natural resources by [[mining]], [[quarrying]], [[Boring (earth)|drilling]], or [[logging|felling]].
According to the [[IRS]] Newswire,<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/article/0,,id=120930,00.html IRS Issues Guidance on Recoverable Reserves]</ref> over 50 percent of oil and gas extraction businesses use cost depletion to figure their depletion deduction. Mineral property includes oil and gas wells, mines, and other natural deposits (including geothermal deposits). For that purpose, property is each separate interest businesses own in each [[mineral deposit]] in each separate tract or parcel of land. Businesses can treat two or more separate interests as one property or as separate properties.
==Types of depletion== For tax purposes, the two types of depletion are percentage depletion and cost depletion.
For mineral property, one generally must use the method that gives you the larger deduction. For standing timber, one must use cost depletion.<ref name="irs.gov">[https://www.irs.gov/publications/p535/ch09.html Publication 535 (2007), Business Expenses]</ref>
===Percentage depletion=== To figure percentage depletion, one multiplies a certain percentage, specified for each mineral, by gross income from the property during the tax year. The rates to be used and other conditions and qualifications for oil and gas wells are discussed below under ''Independent Producers and Royalty Owners'' and under ''Natural Gas Wells''. Rates and other rules for percentage depletion of other specific minerals are found later in ''Mines and Geothermal Deposits''.<ref name="irs.gov"/>
===Cost depletion=== Cost depletion is an accounting method by which costs of natural resources are allocated to depletion over the period that make up the life of the asset. Cost depletion is computed by estimating the total quantity of mineral or other resources acquired and assigning a proportionate amount of the total resource cost to the quantity extracted in the period. For example, if Big Texas Oil, Co. discovers a large reserve of oil, the company has estimated the oil well will produce 200,000 barrels of oil. The company invests $100,000 to extract the oil and extracts 10,000 barrels the first year. Therefore, the depletion deduction is $5,000 ($100,000 X 10,000/200,000).
Cost depletion for tax purposes may be completely different from cost depletion for accounting purposes:
:<math>CD = S/(R+S) \times AB = AB/(R+S) \times S </math> :CD = Cost Depletion. :S = Units sold in the current year :R = Reserves on hand at the end of the current year :AB = Adjusted basis of the property at the end of the current year
==Accounting== Adjusted basis is the basis at end of year adjusted for prior years depletion in cost or percentage. It automatically allows for adjustments to the basis during the taxable year.
By using the units remaining at the end of the year, the adjustment automatically allows for revised estimates of the reserves.
Depletion is based upon sales and not production. Units are considered sold in the year the proceeds are taxable under the taxpayer's accounting method.
==Reserves== Reserves generally include proven developed reserves and "probable" or "prospective" reserves if there is reasonable evidence to have believed that such quantities existed at that time.
==Example== If producer X has capitalized costs on property A of $40,000, originally consisting of the lease bonus, capitalized exploration costs, and some capitalized carrying costs, and the lease has been producing for several years and during this time, X has claimed $10,000 of allowable depletion. In 2009, X's share of production sold was 40,000 barrels and an engineer's report indicated that 160,000 barrels could be recovered after December 31, 2009.
The calculation of cost depletion for this lease would be as follows:
:Cost depletion = S/(R+S) × AB or AB/(R+S) × S :CD = 40,000/(40,000 + 160,000) × ($40,000 − $10,000) : = 40,000/200,000 × $30,000 : = $6,000
==See also== * [[Depreciation]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Shulman, Peter A., “The Making of a Tax Break: The Oil Depletion Allowance, Scientific Taxation, and Natural Resources Policy in the Early Twentieth Century,” ''Journal of Policy History'' (2011), 23#3 pp 281–322.
[[Category:Corporate taxation]] [[Category:Asset]] [[Category:Expense]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=[[academic probation]] which is the initial probationary period in the employment of an academic, or [[scholastic probation]] which is the result of a student having low grade point averages}}
'''Disciplinary probation''' is a disciplinary status that can apply to [[student]]s at a higher educational institution<ref name=Knowles1977 /> or to [[employee]]s in the workplace.<ref name=Pell2003 /> For employees, it can result from both poor performance at work or from misconduct.<ref name=Pell2003 /> For students, it results from misconduct alone, with poor academic performance instead resulting in [[scholastic probation]].<ref name=Knowles1977 />
For a student, disciplinary probation means that the student is on formal notice, and subject to special rules and regulations.<ref name=Knowles1977 /><ref name=BradySnoxell1965 /> The violation of these rules may lead to more severe forms of discipline, such as suspension, dismissal, and expulsion.<ref name=BradySnoxell1965 />
For employees, disciplinary probation is one common step in a scheme of [[progressive discipline]]. It is a common replacement, in non-unionized workplaces, for the progressive disciplinary step of suspension without pay. A usual period for such probation is 90 days.<ref name=Grote2006 /> Some companies may place permanent employees on probationary status, particularly if their performance is below a set standard or for disciplinary reasons. In this instance, the employee is usually given a period of time to either improve their performance or modify their behaviour before more severe measures are taken.
==See also== *[[Probation (workplace)]]
== References == <references> <ref name=Knowles1977>{{cite encyclopaedia|article=disciplinary probation|encyclopedia=International encyclopedia of higher education|volume=1|author=Asa Smallidge Knowles|publisher=Jossey-Bass|date=1977|isbn=978-0-87589-324-2}}</ref> <ref name=Pell2003>{{cite book|pages=350|title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Managing People|series=Complete Idiot's Guides|author=Arthur R. Pell|edition=3rd|publisher=Alpha Books|year=2003|isbn=978-1-59257-145-1|chapter=Putting Employees on Probation}} {{ISBN|159257145X}}.</ref> <ref name=BradySnoxell1965>{{cite book|title=Student discipline in higher education|volume=5|series=Student personnel series|author=Thomas Allan Brady and L. F. Snoxell|publisher=American Personnel and Guidance Association|year=1965|pages=6}}</ref> <ref name=Grote2006>{{cite book|pages=5–8|title=Discipline without punishment|author=Richard C. Grote|edition=2nd|publisher=AMACOM Div American Mgmt Assn|year=2006|isbn=978-0-8144-7330-6}}</ref> </references>
== Further reading == * {{Cite web|publisher=[[Washington State Legislature]]|title=WAC 478-120-040: Disciplinary sanctions|url=http://apps.leg.wa.gov/wac/default.aspx?cite=478-120-040|work=Washington Administrative Code|author=board of regents of the [[University of Washington]]|year=1972}} — an example of university regulations governing disciplinary probation * {{Cite web|url=http://publicpersonnellaw.blogspot.com/2010/06/disciplinary-probation.html|title=Disciplinary probation|date=2010-06-21|author=Harvey Randall|publisher=Public Employment Law Press|issn=1937-4895|work=New York Public Personnel Law}} — analysis of some New York State case law regarding disciplinary probation * {{Cite web|url=http://hrmguide.net./canada/law/federal/disciplinary-probation.htm|date=April 2005|title=Disciplinary Probation|author=Yosie Saint-Cyr|publisher=First Reference|work=HRM Guide}} — disciplinary probation in Canadian employment law * {{Cite journal|title=Commentary: Probation can be a dicey proposition|journal=Daily Journal of Commerce|location=Portland, OR|date=2008-02-29|author=Paula A Barran}} — Barran's advice to employers for the terms to set for disciplinary probation
[[Category:Human resource management]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 812255401 by [[Special:Contributions/203.213.22.127|203.213.22.127]] ([[User talk:203.213.22.127|talk]]) - that may be a list of sequencers, but this should be the one that the group uses.
revision.text:
'''Farbrausch''', or '''Farb-rausch''', is a [[Germany|German]] group of [[demogroup|demomakers]] who became well known in the [[demoscene]] in December 2000 with a [[64k intro]] called "fr-08: .the .product". The demo achieved its small size through the use of [[procedural textures]], a custom MIDI-based [[software synthesizer]] V2 (controlled through a sequencer called [[Logic Audio]]), and a modified version of [[UPX]] executable compressor,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soyoucode.com/2011/coding-giant-under-microscope-farbrausch |title = Coding a giant under the microscope: Farbrausch}}</ref> ".the .product" is an 11-minute [[3D computer graphics|3-D]] show featuring complex scenes of [[computer generated imagery]].
Their work has won numerous awards. In 2004, a subdivision of farbrausch called "'''.theprodukkt'''" released a 96kB first-person shooter game named "[[.kkrieger]]", and an earlier version of the [[demomaker|tool]] they currently use to produce some of their demos, named "[[.werkkzeug]]", or "Tool".
Farbrausch gives their releases a "product code", in the format "fr-0#". The numbers do not specify the order of release — the members have stated that they allocate the numbers as they start working on the project, not when they finish it. Non-serious releases receive negative numbers.
The group has periodically released improved compositions such as "fr-019: Poem to a Horse", "fr-030: Candytron" or "fr-025: The.Popular.Demo". ''The.Popular.Demo'' and ''debris.'' are among the most highly favored demos on the demoscene index, [[Pouët|Pouet]]. The.Popular.Demo also received the "Public Choice Award" from the 2003 scene.org awards, and ''debris.'' won the 2007 scene.org award for best direction.
In 2009, Farbrausch released [[.detuned]], an interactive demo for the [[PlayStation 3]], again under the name .theprodukkt.
In 2012 Farbrausch released the [[source code]] of many of their demotools on [[github.com]].<ref>[https://github.com/farbrausch/fr_public fr_public] on github.com</ref>
== Notable demo releases and awards ==

The Product) |64kB intro |1st place at [[The Party (demo party)|The Party]] 2000 |- |[http://www.pouet.net/prod.php?which=1915 fr-010: Art] (in cooperation with [[Scoopex]]) |64kB intro |1st place at [[Mekka & Symposium]] 2001 |- |[http://pouet.net/prod.php?which=1473 fr-011: ms2001 invitation] |64kB intro |1st place at Mekka & Symposium 2001 |- |[http://pouet.net/prod.php?which=1922 fr-012: kapital] |demo |4th at Mekka & Symposium 2001 |- |[http://www.pouet.net/prod.php?which=4484 fr-013: Flybye] |invitation intro |for The Party 2001 |- |[http://www.pouet.net/prod.php?which=5235 fr-018: AGB] |[[Game Boy Advance|GBA]] demo |1st place at Woest 2002 (wild demo) |- |[http://www.pouet.net/prod.php?which=5569 fr-019: Poem to a Horse] |64kB intro |1st place at Mekka & Symposium 2002, [[Scene.org Awards|scene.org award]] nominee - revision.text:
{{More footnotes|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Friedrich Mandl |image = |alt = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1900|02|09|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria-Hungary]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1977|09|08|1900|02|09|df=y}} |death_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] |nationality = |other_names = |occupation = |known_for = |spouse = Helene Strauss (divorced)
[[Hedy Lamarr]] (m. 1933–37; divorced)
Herta Wrany (divorced)
Gloria de Quaranta (divorced)
Monika Brücklmeier }} '''Friedrich ('Fritz') Mandl''' (9 February 1900 – 8 September 1977) was chairman of [[Hirtenberg]]er [[Otto Eberhardt Patronenfabrik|Patronen-Fabrik]], a leading Austrian armaments firm founded by his father, Alexander Mandl. [[Image:Wöllersdorf Feuerwerksfabrik 2.JPG|300px|thumb|The Wöllersdorfer cartridge factory, from October 1933, the site of the holding camp [[Wöllersdorf]]]] A prominent [[fascist]], Mandl was attached to the [[Austrofascism]] and Italian varieties and an [[German resistance to Nazism|opponent of Nazism]]. In the 1930s he became close to Prince [[Ernst Rüdiger Starhemberg]], the commander of the Austrian nationalist militia ("[[Heimwehr]]"), which he furnished with weapons and ammunition. Until 1940, Mandl tried to establish contact with [[Hermann Göring]]'s office in order to supply Germany with iron. ==Marriages== Mandl was married five times. His wives were: Helene Hella Mandl, Née Strauss, born 1899, Vienna{{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Helene-Mandl/6000000010733147221|title=Helene Hella Mandl|publisher=geni.com|access-date=19 July 2018}} to whom he was married at the age of 21- the marriage lasted for six weeks. [[Hedy Lamarr]], Née Kiesler, born 1914, Vienna (see below){{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Fredrich-Mandl/6000000009716686400|title=Fredrich Alexander Maria (Fritz) Mandl|publisher=geni.com|access-date=19 July 2018}}[https://www.geni.com/people/Hedy-Lamarr/6000000009710927263 Hedwig Eva Maria Kiesler, Also Known As: "Hedy Lamarr"] ''geni.com'', accessed 19 July 2018They married in 1933 and divorced in 1937 or 1938. Herta Mandl, Née Wrany, born 1911, Steiermark{{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Herta-Mandl/6000000010732659113|title=Herta Mandl|publisher=geni.com|access-date=19 July 2018}} (The LaVoz article suggests she was also known as Schneider, and was with him in Buenos Aires in 1938) They married in 1939 and divorced in 1951. Gloria de Quaranta, Née Vinelli, born 1922, Buenos Aires{{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Gloria-de-Quaranta/6000000010733113363|title=Gloria de Quaranta|publisher=geni.com|access-date=19 July 2018}} They married in 1951; she died in 1976. Mandl's last marriage was to his secretary Monika Brücklmeier, daughter of [[Eduard Brücklmeier]], an accessory executed for his involvement in the [[July 20 plot]] to assassinate Hitler.{{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Monika-Mandl/6000000010732717957|title=Monika Mandl|publisher=geni.com|access-date=19 July 2018}} ==Marriage to Hedy Lamarr== From 1933 to 1937, Mandl was married to Austrian actress Hedwig "Hedy" Kiesler, who would later become known as Hedy Lamarr in [[Hollywood]]. Both Hedy Lamarr's parents were born Jewish, but her mother converted to Roman Catholicism and Hedy was brought up Catholic. Her first "serious" film was ''[[Algiers (film)|Algiers]]'' for which she was highly acclaimed at the time. Mandl is rumoured to have attempted to bring a halt to her acting career in Germany and to purchase all copies of her infamous film ''[[Ecstasy (film)|Ecstasy]]'' (1933), in which she appeared nude.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} Following incorporation of Austria into [[Nazi Germany]] with the [[Anschluss]] of 1938, Mandl's remaining property which had not yet been transferred to Swiss ownership was seized, since he had supported the separatist Austrofascism. His then-wife Lamarr wrote in her autobiography ''Ecstasy and Me'', that both Italian dictator [[Benito Mussolini]] and German dictator [[Adolf Hitler]] attended Mandl's parties. Lamarr described Mandl as extremely controlling, and wrote that she escaped only by disguising herself as a maid and fleeing to [[Paris]], where she obtained a divorce.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} ==Later years== Mandl later moved to Brazil and then to Argentina, where he became a citizen and remarried. In Argentina he served as an advisor to [[Juan Perón]] and attempted a new role as film producer. He also founded a new airplane manufacturing firm, Industria Metalúrgica y Plástica Argentina. Mandl became a leading member of Argentina's social circles. He acquired homes in [[Mar del Plata]], a castle in [[Córdoba, Argentina|Córdoba]] and a small hotel in [[Buenos Aires]].{{cite web|url=http://archivo.lavoz.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=47377|title=LAVOZ.com.ar - Los secretos del castillo de Fritz Mandl - Página|publisher=lavoz.com.ar|access-date=19 July 2018}} He worked closely with French designer [[Jean-Michel Frank]], who was then artistic director of Comte S.A.,Pierre-Emmanuel Martin-Viver; "JEAN-MICHEL FRANK - The Strange and Subtle Luxury of the Parisian Haute-Monde in the Art Deco Period"; pp. 74, 257–58. who produced most of Mandl's furnishings. In 1955 he returned to Austria, where he resumed running the factory at Hirtenberg.Fritz Hanauska: Heimatbuch der Marktgemeinde Hirtenberg. Marktgemeinde Hirtenberg, Hirtenberg 1980 == References == {{Reflist}} == General references == * Bill, Ramón. Waffenfabrik Solothurn. Schweizerische Präzision im Dienste der deutschen Rüstungsindustrie. In: Schriftenreihe des Kantonalen Museums Altes Zeughaus Solothurn, Heft 14. Solothurn, 2002 * Hug, Peter. Schweizer Rüstungsindustrie und Kriegsmaterialhandel zur Zeit des Nationalsozialismus. Unternehmensstrategien – Marktentwicklung – politische Überwachung. Zurich: Chronos Verlag, Band 11 der Publikationen der Unabhängigen Expertenkommission, 2002. * Kerekes, Lajos. Abenddämmerung einer Demokratie. Mussolini, Gömbös und die Heimwehr. Wien-Frankfurt-Zürich: Europa Verlag, 1966. * Louçã, António. Conspiradores e traficantes. Portugal no tráfico de armas e de divisas nos anos do nazismo. 1933-1945. Lisbon: Oficina do Livro, 2005. * Hanauska, Fritz. Heimatbuch der Marktgemeinde Hirtenberg. Marktgemeinde Hirtenberg, Hirtenberg 1980 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mandl, Friedrich}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1977 deaths]] [[Category:Austrian businesspeople]] [[Category:Argentine businesspeople]] [[Category:Austrian emigrants to Argentina]] [[Category:Arms traders]]
